   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Colombia
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div class="noprint" id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>

     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       This article is about the country. For other uses and spellings, see
       <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Colombia_(disambiguation)" title="Colombia (disambiguation)">
        Colombia (disambiguation)
       </a>
       .
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Not to be confused with
       <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Columbia_(disambiguation)" title="Columbia (disambiguation)">
        Columbia (disambiguation)
       </a>
       .
      </div>

          Recognized regional languages
         </span>
        </th>
        <td>
         68 ethnic languages and dialects.
         <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
          English
         </a>
         is also official in the
         <a href="/wiki/Archipelago_of_San_Andr%C3%A9s,_Providencia_and_Santa_Catalina" title="Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina">
          archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina
         </a>

        <th scope="row">

         <div class="plainlist">
          <ul>
           <li>
            86%
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mestizo_Colombian" title="Mestizo Colombian">
             Mestizo
            </a>
            and
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_Colombian" title="White Colombian">
             White
            </a>
            ;
           </li>
           <li>
            10.6%
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afro-Colombian" title="Afro-Colombian">
             Black
            </a>
           </li>
           <li>
            <small>
             (includes
             <a href="/wiki/Mulatto" title="Mulatto">
              Mulatto
             </a>
             )
            </small>
            ;
           </li>
           <li>
            3.4%
            <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">
             Amerindian
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>

       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
          <ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em; font-size:90%;">
           <li value="1">
            Although the Colombian Constitution specifies Spanish (
            <i>
             Castellano
            </i>
            ) as the official language in all Colombian territory, other languages spoken in the country by ethnic groups – approximately 68 languages – each is also official in its own territory.
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
             <a href="#cite_note-7">
              [7]
             </a>
            </sup>
            English is also official in the
            <a href="/wiki/Archipelago_of_San_Andr%C3%A9s,_Providencia_and_Santa_Catalina" title="Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina">
             archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina
            </a>
            .
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LEY47DE1993_8-0">
             <a href="#cite_note-LEY47DE1993-8">
              [8]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
           <li value="2">
            The official Colombian time
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
             <a href="#cite_note-9">
              [9]
             </a>
            </sup>
            is controlled and coordinated by the
            <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=National_Institute_of_Metrology_(Colombia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="National Institute of Metrology (Colombia) (page does not exist)">
             National Institute of Metrology
            </a>
            .
            <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
             <a href="#cite_note-10">
              [10]
             </a>
            </sup>
           </li>
          </ol>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <b>
        Colombia
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="'k' in 'kind'">
            k
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="'l' in 'lie'">
            l
           </span>
           <span title="/ʌ/: 'u' in 'cut'">
            ʌ
           </span>
           <span title="'m' in 'my'">
            m
           </span>
           <span title="'b' in 'buy'">
            b
           </span>
           <span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">
            i
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
          </span>
          , -
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="'l' in 'lie'">
            l
           </span>
           <span title="/ɒ/: 'o' in 'body'">
            ɒ
           </span>
           <span title="'m' in 'my'">
            m
           </span>
          </span>
          -/
         </a>
        </span>
       </span>
       <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key">
        <i title="English pronunciation respelling">
         kə-
         <span style="font-size:90%">
          LUM
         </span>
         -bee-ə,
         <span style="font-size:90%">
          -LOM-
         </span>
        </i>
       </a>
       ;
       <small>
        Spanish:
       </small>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">
         [koˈlombja]
        </a>
       </span>
       <small class="nowrap">
        (
        <span class="unicode haudio">
         <span class="fn">
          <span style="white-space:nowrap">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Es-colombia.ogg" title="About this sound">
            <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
           </a>
          </span>
          <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/de/Es-colombia.ogg" title="Es-colombia.ogg">
           listen
          </a>
         </span>
        </span>
        )
       </small>
       ), officially the
       <b>
        Republic of Colombia
       </b>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish
       </a>
       :
       <span class="unicode haudio">
        <span class="fn">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Es-republica_de_colombia.ogg" title="About this sound">
           <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ed/Es-republica_de_colombia.ogg" title="Es-republica de colombia.ogg">
          <span class="unicode" lang="es">
           <i>
            República de Colombia
           </i>
          </span>
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">
         (
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           help
          </span>
         </a>
         ·
         <a href="/wiki/File:Es-republica_de_colombia.ogg" title="File:Es-republica de colombia.ogg">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           info
          </span>
         </a>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
        <a href="#cite_note-11">
         [Note 1]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is a
       <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">
        sovereign state
       </a>
       largely situated in the northwest of
       <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">
        South America
       </a>
       , with
       <a href="/wiki/Insular_region_of_Colombia" title="Insular region of Colombia">
        territories
       </a>
       in Central America. Colombia shares a border to the northwest with
       <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">
        Panama
       </a>
       , to the east with
       <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">
        Venezuela
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">
        Brazil
       </a>
       and to the south with
       <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">
        Ecuador
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">
        Peru
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Land_borders_12-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Land_borders-12">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It shares its maritime limits with
       <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">
        Costa Rica
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Nicaragua" title="Nicaragua">
        Nicaragua
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Honduras" title="Honduras">
        Honduras
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">
        Jamaica
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">
        Haiti
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">
        Dominican Republic
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maritime_borders_13-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Maritime_borders-13">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is a
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary
       </a>
       , constitutional
       <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">
        republic
       </a>
       comprising thirty-two
       <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_Colombia" title="Departments of Colombia">
        departments
       </a>
       . The territory of what is now Colombia was originally inhabited by
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">
        indigenous peoples
       </a>
       , including the
       <a href="/wiki/Muisca" title="Muisca">
        Muisca
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Quimbaya_civilization" title="Quimbaya civilization">
        Quimbaya
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Tairona" title="Tairona">
        Tairona
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The Spanish set foot on Colombian soil for the first time in 1499 and in the first half of the 16th century initiated a period of
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Muisca" title="Spanish conquest of the Muisca">
        conquest and colonization
       </a>
       , ultimately creating the
       <a href="/wiki/New_Kingdom_of_Granada" title="New Kingdom of Granada">
        New Kingdom of Granada
       </a>
       , with as capital
       <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">
        Santafé de Bogotá
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_American_wars_of_independence" title="Spanish American wars of independence">
        Independence
       </a>
       from
       <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
        Spain
       </a>
       was acquired in 1819, but by 1830 the "
       <a href="/wiki/Gran_Colombia" title="Gran Colombia">
        Gran Colombia
       </a>
       " Federation was dissolved. What is now Colombia and Panama emerged as the
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_New_Granada" title="Republic of New Granada">
        Republic of New Granada
       </a>
       . The new nation experimented with federalism as the
       <a href="/wiki/Granadine_Confederation" title="Granadine Confederation">
        Granadine Confederation
       </a>
       (1858), and then the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Colombia" title="United States of Colombia">
        United States of Colombia
       </a>
       (1863), before the Republic of Colombia was finally declared in 1886.
       <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_Panama_from_Colombia" title="Separation of Panama from Colombia">
        Panama seceded
       </a>
       in 1903. Since the 1960s, the country has suffered from an asymmetric low-intensity
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_armed_conflict_(1964%E2%80%93present)" title="Colombian armed conflict (1964–present)">
        armed conflict
       </a>
       , which escalated in the 1990s but then decreased from 2005 onward.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enough_Already!_14-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Enough_Already!-14">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia is one of the most
       <a href="/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_Colombia" title="Race and ethnicity in Colombia">
        ethnically
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Colombia" title="Languages of Colombia">
        linguistically
       </a>
       diverse countries in the world, and thereby possesses a rich
       <a href="/wiki/Cultural_heritage" title="Cultural heritage">
        cultural heritage
       </a>
       . The urban centres are mostly located in the highlands of the
       <a href="/wiki/Andean_natural_region" title="Andean natural region">
        Andes mountains
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Colombian territory also encompasses
       <a href="/wiki/Amazon_natural_region" title="Amazon natural region">
        Amazon rainforest
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Orinoqu%C3%ADa_natural_region" title="Orinoquía natural region">
        tropical grassland
       </a>
       and both
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_natural_region" title="Caribbean natural region">
        Caribbean
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Pacific/Choc%C3%B3_natural_region" title="Pacific/Chocó natural region">
        Pacific
       </a>
       coastlines. Ecologically, it is one of the world's 17
       <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">
        megadiverse countries
       </a>
       , and the most densely
       <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_of_Colombia" title="Biodiversity of Colombia">
        biodiverse
       </a>
       of these per square kilometer.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Biodiversity_of_Colombia_15-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Biodiversity_of_Colombia-15">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia is a
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">
        middle power
       </a>
       and a
       <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">
        regional actor
       </a>
       with the fourth-largest economy in Latin America,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imf2_4-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-imf2-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is part of the
       <a href="/wiki/CIVETS" title="CIVETS">
        CIVETS
       </a>
       group of six leading
       <a href="/wiki/Emerging_markets" title="Emerging markets">
        emerging markets
       </a>
       and is a member of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN" title="UN">
        UN
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WTO" title="WTO">
        WTO
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">
        OAS
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Alliance" title="Pacific Alliance">
        Pacific Alliance
       </a>
       , and other international organizations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia has a diversified economy with macroeconomic stability and favorable growth prospects in the long run.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDP_17-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GDP-17">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-strongpolicyframework_18-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-strongpolicyframework-18">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>

      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
        Etymology
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="690" data-file-width="500" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg/140px-Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg/210px-Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg/280px-Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg 2x" width="140"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          Colombia
         </i>
         is named after
         <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">
          Christopher Columbus
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The name "Colombia" is derived from the last name of
       <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">
        Christopher Columbus
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="it">
         Cristoforo Colombo
        </span>
       </i>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         Cristóbal Colón
        </span>
       </i>
       ). It was conceived by the Venezuelan revolutionary
       <a href="/wiki/Francisco_de_Miranda" title="Francisco de Miranda">
        Francisco de Miranda
       </a>
       as a reference to all the New World, but especially to those portions under Spanish rule (by then from Mississippi river to Patagonia). The name was later adopted by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Colombia" title="Greater Colombia">
        Republic of Colombia
       </a>
       of 1819, formed from the territories of the old
       <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada" title="Viceroyalty of New Granada">
        Viceroyalty of New Granada
       </a>
       (modern-day Colombia, Panama, Venezuela, Ecuador, and northwest Brazil).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LABLAA5_19-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LABLAA5-19">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       When Venezuela, Ecuador and
       <a href="/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department_(1820)" title="Cundinamarca Department (1820)">
        Cundinamarca
       </a>
       came to exist as independent states, the former
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cundinamarca_Province" title="Cundinamarca Province">
        Department of Cundinamarca
       </a>
       adopted the name "
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_New_Granada" title="Republic of New Granada">
        Republic of New Granada
       </a>
       ". New Granada officially changed its name in 1858 to the
       <a href="/wiki/Granadine_Confederation" title="Granadine Confederation">
        Granadine Confederation
       </a>
       . In 1863 the name was again changed, this time to
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Colombia" title="United States of Colombia">
        United States of Colombia
       </a>
       , before finally adopting its present name – the Republic of Colombia – in 1886.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LABLAA5_19-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-LABLAA5-19">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       To refer to this country, the Colombian government uses the terms
       <i>
        Colombia
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        República de Colombia
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Colombia" title="History of Colombia">
        History of Colombia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Colombian_history" title="Timeline of Colombian history">
        Timeline of Colombian history
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Columbian_era">
        Pre-Columbian era
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:423px;max-width:423px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:192px;max-width:192px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Parque_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_de_San_Agust%C3%ADn_-_tomb_of_a_deity_with_supporting_warriors.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1319" data-file-width="1989" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Parque_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_de_San_Agust%C3%ADn_-_tomb_of_a_deity_with_supporting_warriors.jpg/190px-Parque_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_de_San_Agust%C3%ADn_-_tomb_of_a_deity_with_supporting_warriors.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Parque_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_de_San_Agust%C3%ADn_-_tomb_of_a_deity_with_supporting_warriors.jpg/285px-Parque_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_de_San_Agust%C3%ADn_-_tomb_of_a_deity_with_supporting_warriors.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Parque_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_de_San_Agust%C3%ADn_-_tomb_of_a_deity_with_supporting_warriors.jpg/380px-Parque_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_de_San_Agust%C3%ADn_-_tomb_of_a_deity_with_supporting_warriors.jpg 2x" width="190"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/San_Agust%C3%ADn_Archaeological_Park" title="San Agustín Archaeological Park">
           San Agustín Archaeological Park
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:227px;max-width:227px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lost_City_Ruins.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1149" data-file-width="2048" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Lost_City_Ruins.jpg/225px-Lost_City_Ruins.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Lost_City_Ruins.jpg/338px-Lost_City_Ruins.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Lost_City_Ruins.jpg/450px-Lost_City_Ruins.jpg 2x" width="225"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Perdida" title="Ciudad Perdida">
           Ciudad Perdida
          </a>
          ("The Lost City")
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Owing to its location, the present territory of Colombia was a corridor of early human migration from
       <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerica" title="Mesoamerica">
        Mesoamerica
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">
        Caribbean
       </a>
       to the
       <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">
        Andes
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Amazon_basin" title="Amazon basin">
        Amazon basin
       </a>
       . The oldest archaeological finds are from the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Pubenza_archaeological_site&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pubenza archaeological site (page does not exist)">
        Pubenza
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=El_Totumo_archaeological_site&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="El Totumo archaeological site (page does not exist)">
        El Totumo
       </a>
       sites in the Magdalena Valley 100 kilometres (62 mi) southwest of Bogotá.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These sites date from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paleoindian" title="Paleoindian">
        Paleoindian
       </a>
       period (18,000–8000 BCE). At
       <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Hormiga_archaeological_site" title="Puerto Hormiga archaeological site">
        Puerto Hormiga
       </a>
       and other sites, traces from the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Archaic_period_in_South_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Archaic period in South America (page does not exist)">
        Archaic Period
       </a>
       (~8000–2000 BCE) have been found. Vestiges indicate that there was also early occupation in the regions of
       <a href="/wiki/El_Abra" title="El Abra">
        El Abra
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tequendama_(archaeological_site)" title="Tequendama (archaeological site)">
        Tequendama
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department_(1820)" title="Cundinamarca Department (1820)">
        Cundinamarca
       </a>
       . The oldest pottery discovered in the Americas, found at
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=San_Jacinto_archaeological_site&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="San Jacinto archaeological site (page does not exist)">
        San Jacinto
       </a>
       , dates to 5000–4000 BCE.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="438" data-file-width="584" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg/220px-Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg/330px-Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg/440px-Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Muisca_raft" title="Muisca raft">
          Muisca raft
         </a>
         . The figure refers to the ceremony of the legend of
         <a href="/wiki/El_Dorado" title="El Dorado">
          El Dorado
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Indigenous people inhabited the territory that is now Colombia by 12,500 BCE. Nomadic
       <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">
        hunter-gatherer
       </a>
       tribes at the
       <a href="/wiki/El_Abra" title="El Abra">
        El Abra
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tibit%C3%B3" title="Tibitó">
        Tibitó
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Tequendama" title="Tequendama">
        Tequendama
       </a>
       sites near present-day
       <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">
        Bogotá
       </a>
       traded with one another and with other cultures from the
       <a href="/wiki/Magdalena_River" title="Magdalena River">
        Magdalena River
       </a>
       Valley.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Between 5000 and 1000 BCE, hunter-gatherer tribes transitioned to agrarian societies; fixed settlements were established, and pottery appeared. Beginning in the 1st millennium BCE, groups of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amerindian" title="Amerindian">
        Amerindians
       </a>
       including the
       <a href="/wiki/Muisca" title="Muisca">
        Muisca
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Zen%C3%BA" title="Zenú">
        Zenú
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Quimbaya_civilization" title="Quimbaya civilization">
        Quimbaya
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Tairona" title="Tairona">
        Tairona
       </a>
       developed the political system of
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Cacicazgo" title="Cacicazgo">
         cacicazgos
        </a>
       </i>
       with a pyramidal structure of power headed by
       <a href="/wiki/Cacique_Nutibara_Bloc" title="Cacique Nutibara Bloc">
        caciques
       </a>
       . The Muisca inhabited mainly the area of what is now the
       <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_Colombia" title="Departments of Colombia">
        Departments
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Boyac%C3%A1_Department" title="Boyacá Department">
        Boyacá
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department" title="Cundinamarca Department">
        Cundinamarca
       </a>
       high plateau (
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Altiplano_Cundiboyacense" title="Altiplano Cundiboyacense">
         Altiplano Cundiboyacense
        </a>
       </i>
       ) where they formed the
       <a href="/wiki/Muisca_Confederation" title="Muisca Confederation">
        Muisca Confederation
       </a>
       . They farmed maize, potato, quinoa and cotton, and traded gold,
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_emeralds" title="Colombian emeralds">
        emeralds
       </a>
       , blankets, ceramic handicrafts, coca and especially
       <a href="/wiki/Halite" title="Halite">
        rock salt
       </a>
       with neighboring nations. The Tairona inhabited northern Colombia in the isolated mountain range of
       <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_de_Santa_Marta" title="Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta">
        Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Quimbaya inhabited regions of the
       <a href="/wiki/Cauca_River" title="Cauca River">
        Cauca River
       </a>
       Valley between the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cordillera_Occidental,_Colombia" title="Cordillera Occidental, Colombia">
        Western
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cordillera_Central,_Colombia" title="Cordillera Central, Colombia">
        Central
       </a>
       Ranges of the Colombian Andes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Most of the Amerindians practiced agriculture and the social structure of each indigenous community was different. Some groups of indigenous people such as the Caribs lived in a state of permanent war, but others had less bellicose attitudes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Incas expanded their
       <a href="/wiki/Inca_Empire" title="Inca Empire">
        empire
       </a>
       onto the southwest part of the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
        <a href="#cite_note-26">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Spanish_conquest">
        Spanish conquest
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2127" data-file-width="1163" height="329" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg/180px-1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg/270px-1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg/360px-1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Map_of_Juan_de_la_Cosa" title="Map of Juan de la Cosa">
          Map of Juan de la Cosa
         </a>
         . It is the oldest known European cartographic representation of the New World.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Alonso_de_Ojeda" title="Alonso de Ojeda">
        Alonso de Ojeda
       </a>
       (who had sailed with Columbus) reached the
       <a href="/wiki/Guajira_Peninsula" title="Guajira Peninsula">
        Guajira Peninsula
       </a>
       in 1499.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LABLAA6_27-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LABLAA6-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Spanish explorers, led by
       <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_de_Bastidas" title="Rodrigo de Bastidas">
        Rodrigo de Bastidas
       </a>
       , made the first exploration of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caribbean_Basin" title="Caribbean Basin">
        Caribbean coast
       </a>
       in 1500.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
        <a href="#cite_note-29">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">
        Christopher Columbus
       </a>
       navigated near the Caribbean in 1502.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
        <a href="#cite_note-30">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1508,
       <a href="/wiki/Vasco_N%C3%BA%C3%B1ez_de_Balboa" title="Vasco Núñez de Balboa">
        Vasco Núñez de Balboa
       </a>
       accompanied an expedition to the territory through the region of
       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Urab%C3%A1" title="Gulf of Urabá">
        Gulf of Urabá
       </a>
       and they founded the town of
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Mar%C3%ADa_la_Antigua_del_Dari%C3%A9n" title="Santa María la Antigua del Darién">
        Santa María la Antigua del Darién
       </a>
       in 1510, the first stable settlement on the continent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
        <a href="#cite_note-31">
         [Note 2]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
        <a href="#cite_note-32">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Marta" title="Santa Marta">
        Santa Marta
       </a>
       was founded in 1525,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
        <a href="#cite_note-33">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">
        Cartagena
       </a>
       in 1533.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Spanish
       <a href="/wiki/Conquistador" title="Conquistador">
        conquistador
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Gonzalo_Jim%C3%A9nez_de_Quesada" title="Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada">
        Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada
       </a>
       led an expedition to the interior in April 1536, and christened the districts through which he passed "
       <a href="/wiki/New_Kingdom_of_Granada" title="New Kingdom of Granada">
        New Kingdom of Granada
       </a>
       ". In August 1538, he founded provisionally its capital near the Muisca
       <a href="/wiki/Cacicazgo" title="Cacicazgo">
        cacicazgo
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Bacat%C3%A1" title="Bacatá">
        Bacatá
       </a>
       , and named it "Santa Fe". The name soon acquired a suffix and was called Santa Fe de Bogotá.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
        <a href="#cite_note-35">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Two other notable journeys by early conquistadors to the interior took place in the same period.
       <a href="/wiki/Sebasti%C3%A1n_de_Belalc%C3%A1zar" title="Sebastián de Belalcázar">
        Sebastián de Belalcázar
       </a>
       , conqueror of
       <a href="/wiki/Quito" title="Quito">
        Quito
       </a>
       , traveled north and founded
       <a href="/wiki/Cali" title="Cali">
        Cali
       </a>
       , in 1536, and
       <a href="/wiki/Popay%C3%A1n" title="Popayán">
        Popayán
       </a>
       , in 1537;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       from 1536 to 1539, German conquistador
       <a href="/wiki/Nikolaus_Federmann" title="Nikolaus Federmann">
        Nikolaus Federmann
       </a>
       crossed the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orinoqu%C3%ADa_Natural_Region,_Colombia" title="Orinoquía Natural Region, Colombia">
        Llanos Orientales
       </a>
       and went over the
       <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_Oriental_(Colombia)" title="Cordillera Oriental (Colombia)">
        Cordillera Oriental
       </a>
       in a search for
       <a href="/wiki/El_Dorado" title="El Dorado">
        El Dorado
       </a>
       , the "city of gold".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The legend and the gold would play a pivotal role in luring the Spanish and other Europeans to New Granada during the 16th and 17th centuries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
        <a href="#cite_note-40">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_conquistadors_in_Colombia" title="List of conquistadors in Colombia">
        conquistadors
       </a>
       made frequent alliances with the enemies of different indigenous communities.
       <a href="/wiki/Indian_auxiliaries" title="Indian auxiliaries">
        Indigenous allies
       </a>
       were crucial to conquest, as well as to creating and maintaining empire.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
        <a href="#cite_note-41">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Indigenous peoples in New Granada experienced a decline in population due to conquest as well as Eurasian diseases, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">
        smallpox
       </a>
       , to which they had no immunity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
        <a href="#cite_note-43">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       With the risk that the land was deserted, the Spanish Crown sold properties to all persons interested in colonise territories creating large farms and possession of mines.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TierrasColonia_44-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TierrasColonia-44">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EconomíaColonial_45-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EconomíaColonial-45">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-políticaeconómica_46-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-políticaeconómica-46">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 16th century, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nautical_science" title="Nautical science">
        nautical science
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
        Spain
       </a>
       reached a great development thanks to numerous scientific figures of the
       <a href="/wiki/Casa_de_Contrataci%C3%B3n" title="Casa de Contratación">
        Casa de Contratación
       </a>
       and nautical science was an essential pillar of the
       <a href="/wiki/Iberian_ship_development,_1400%E2%80%931600" title="Iberian ship development, 1400–1600">
        Iberian expansion
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alonso_de_Santa_Cruz_47-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Alonso_de_Santa_Cruz-47">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_period">
        Colonial period
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       In 1542, the region of New Granada, along with all other Spanish possessions in South America, became part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_Peru" title="Viceroyalty of Peru">
        Viceroyalty of Peru
       </a>
       , with its capital at
       <a href="/wiki/Lima" title="Lima">
        Lima
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1547, New Granada became the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Captaincy-General_of_New_Granada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Captaincy-General of New Granada (page does not exist)">
        Captaincy-General of New Granada
       </a>
       within the viceroyalty.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1549, the
       <a href="/wiki/Real_Audiencia" title="Real Audiencia">
        Royal Audiencia
       </a>
       was created by a royal decree, and New Granada was ruled by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Audience_of_Santa_Fe_de_Bogot%C3%A1" title="Royal Audience of Santa Fe de Bogotá">
        Royal Audience of Santa Fe de Bogotá
       </a>
       , which at that time comprised the provinces of Santa Marta, Rio de San Juan, Popayán, Guayana and Cartagena.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       But important decisions were taken from the colony to Spain by the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_Indies" title="Council of the Indies">
        Council of the Indies
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo,_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="795" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/7e/Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg/220px-Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/7e/Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg/330px-Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/7e/Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg/440px-Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo,_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Attack of the British army on Cartagena de Indias.
         <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cartagena_de_Indias" title="Battle of Cartagena de Indias">
          The battle
         </a>
         resulted in a major defeat for the British Navy and Army during the
         <a href="/wiki/War_of_Jenkins%27_Ear" title="War of Jenkins' Ear">
          War of Jenkins' Ear
         </a>
         , 1739–48.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BattleofCartagena_52-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-BattleofCartagena-52">
           [50]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In the 16th century, Europeans began to bring
       <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">
        slaves
       </a>
       from Africa. Spain was the only European power that could not establish
       <a href="/wiki/Factory_(trading_post)" title="Factory (trading post)">
        factories
       </a>
       in Africa to purchase slaves and therefore the Spanish empire relied on the
       <a href="/wiki/Asiento" title="Asiento">
        asiento
       </a>
       system, awarding merchants (mostly from
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">
        Portugal
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">
        France
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/South_Sea_Company#Slave_trade_under_the_Asiento" title="South Sea Company">
        England
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Empire" title="Dutch Empire">
        Dutch Empire
       </a>
       ) the license to trade enslaved people to their overseas territories.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Also there were people who defended the human rights and freedoms of oppressed peoples.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [Note 3]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [Note 4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The indigenous peoples could not be enslaved because they were legally
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commoners" title="Commoners">
        subjects
       </a>
       of the Spanish Crown
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
        <a href="#cite_note-61">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and to protect the indigenous peoples, several forms of land ownership and regulation were established:
       <i>
        resguardos
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        encomiendas
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        haciendas
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TierrasColonia_44-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-TierrasColonia-44">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EconomíaColonial_45-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-EconomíaColonial-45">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-políticaeconómica_46-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-políticaeconómica-46">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="1536" height="267" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg/200px-Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg/300px-Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg/400px-Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Many intellectual leaders of the independence process participated in the
         <a href="/wiki/Royal_Botanical_Expedition_to_New_Granada" title="Royal Botanical Expedition to New Granada">
          Royal Botanical Expedition to New Granada
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1717 the
       <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada" title="Viceroyalty of New Granada">
        Viceroyalty of New Granada
       </a>
       was originally created, and then it was temporarily removed, to finally be reestablished in 1739. The Viceroyalty had Santa Fé de Bogotá as its capital. This Viceroyalty included some other provinces of northwestern South America which had previously been under the jurisdiction of the
       <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">
        Viceroyalties of New Spain
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_Peru" title="Viceroyalty of Peru">
        Peru
       </a>
       and correspond mainly to today's Venezuela, Ecuador and Panama. So, Bogotá became one of the principal administrative centers of the Spanish possessions in the New World, along with
       <a href="/wiki/Lima" title="Lima">
        Lima
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">
        Mexico City
       </a>
       , though it remained somewhat backward compared to those two cities in several economic and logistical ways.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
        <a href="#cite_note-63">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After Great Britain declared war on Spain in 1739,
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cartagena_de_Indias" title="Battle of Cartagena de Indias">
        Cartagena
       </a>
       quickly became the British forces' top target but an upset Spanish victory during the
       <a href="/wiki/War_of_Jenkins%27_Ear" title="War of Jenkins' Ear">
        War of Jenkins' Ear
       </a>
       , a war with Great Britain for economic control of the Caribbean, cemented Spanish dominance in the
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">
        Caribbean
       </a>
       until the
       <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">
        Seven Years' War
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BattleofCartagena_52-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-BattleofCartagena-52">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The 18th-century priest, botanist and mathematician
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis" title="José Celestino Mutis">
        José Celestino Mutis
       </a>
       was delegated by Viceroy
       <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Caballero_y_G%C3%B3ngora" title="Antonio Caballero y Góngora">
        Antonio Caballero y Góngora
       </a>
       to conduct an inventory of the nature of the New Granada. Started in 1783, this became known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Royal_Botanical_Expedition_to_New_Granada" title="Royal Botanical Expedition to New Granada">
        Royal Botanical Expedition to New Granada
       </a>
       which classified plants, wildlife and founded the first astronomical observatory in the city of Santa Fe de Bogotá.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In July 1801 the Prussian scientist
       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt" title="Alexander von Humboldt">
        Alexander von Humboldt
       </a>
       reached Santa Fe de Bogotá where he met with Mutis. In addition, historical figures in the process of independence in New Granada emerged from the expedition as the astronomer
       <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Jos%C3%A9_de_Caldas" title="Francisco José de Caldas">
        Francisco José de Caldas
       </a>
       , the scientist
       <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Antonio_Zea" title="Francisco Antonio Zea">
        Francisco Antonio Zea
       </a>
       , the zoologist
       <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Tadeo_Lozano" title="Jorge Tadeo Lozano">
        Jorge Tadeo Lozano
       </a>
       and the painter
       <a href="/wiki/Salvador_Rizo" title="Salvador Rizo">
        Salvador Rizo
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
        <a href="#cite_note-66">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Independence">
        Independence
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1122" data-file-width="1654" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg/220px-Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg/330px-Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg/440px-Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Boyac%C3%A1" title="Battle of Boyacá">
          Battle of Boyacá
         </a>
         was the decisive battle which would ensure the success of the
         <a href="/wiki/Bol%C3%ADvar%27s_campaign_to_liberate_New_Granada" title="Bolívar's campaign to liberate New Granada">
          liberation campaign of New Granada
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Since the beginning of the periods of conquest and colonization, there were several rebel movements against Spanish rule, but most were either crushed or remained too weak to change the overall situation. The last one that sought outright
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Colombian Declaration of Independence">
        independence from Spain
       </a>
       sprang up around 1810, following the independence of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Domingue" title="St. Domingue">
        St. Domingue
       </a>
       (present-day Haiti) in 1804, which provided some support to an eventual leader of this rebellion:
       <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Simón Bolívar">
        Simón Bolívar
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Francisco_de_Paula_Santander" title="Francisco de Paula Santander">
        Francisco de Paula Santander
       </a>
       also would play a decisive role.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
        <a href="#cite_note-68">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
        <a href="#cite_note-70">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ProvinciaSocorro.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="322" data-file-width="263" height="184" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/ProvinciaSocorro.jpg/150px-ProvinciaSocorro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/ProvinciaSocorro.jpg/225px-ProvinciaSocorro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/ProvinciaSocorro.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ProvinciaSocorro.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Socorro_Province" title="Socorro Province">
          Socorro Province
         </a>
         was the site of the
         <a href="/wiki/Revolt_of_the_Comuneros_(New_Granada)" title="Revolt of the Comuneros (New Granada)">
          genesis
         </a>
         of the independence process.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       A movement was initiated by
       <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Nari%C3%B1o" title="Antonio Nariño">
        Antonio Nariño
       </a>
       , who opposed Spanish centralism and led the opposition against the
       <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty" title="Viceroyalty">
        Viceroyalty
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
        <a href="#cite_note-71">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">
        Cartagena
       </a>
       became independent in November 1811.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1811 the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Provinces_of_New_Granada" title="United Provinces of New Granada">
        United Provinces of New Granada
       </a>
       were proclaimed, headed by
       <a href="/wiki/Camilo_Torres_Tenorio" title="Camilo Torres Tenorio">
        Camilo Torres Tenorio
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The emergence of two distinct ideological currents among the
       <a href="/wiki/Patriot_(Spanish_American_independence)" title="Patriot (Spanish American independence)">
        patriots
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">
        federalism
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        centralism
       </a>
       ) gave rise to a period of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Patria_Boba" title="Patria Boba">
        instability
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
        <a href="#cite_note-75">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Shortly after the
       <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">
        Napoleonic Wars
       </a>
       ended,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ferdinand_VII" title="Ferdinand VII">
        Ferdinand VII
       </a>
       , recently restored to the throne in Spain, unexpectedly decided
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_reconquest_of_New_Granada" title="Spanish reconquest of New Granada">
        to send military forces
       </a>
       to retake most of northern South America. The viceroyalty was restored under the command of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Juan_S%C3%A1mano" title="Juan Sámano">
        Juan Sámano
       </a>
       , whose regime punished those who participated in the patriotic movements, ignoring the political nuances of the
       <a href="/wiki/Junta_(Spanish_American_Independence)" title="Junta (Spanish American Independence)">
        juntas
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The retribution stoked renewed rebellion, which, combined with a weakened Spain, made possible a successful rebellion led by the Venezuelan-born
       <a href="/wiki/Military_career_of_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Military career of Simón Bolívar">
        Simón Bolívar
       </a>
       , who finally proclaimed
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_American_wars_of_independence" title="Spanish American wars of independence">
        independence
       </a>
       in 1819.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Historia_ilustrada_de_Colombia_77-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Historia_ilustrada_de_Colombia-77">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royalist_(Spanish_American_Independence)" title="Royalist (Spanish American Independence)">
        pro-Spanish resistance
       </a>
       was defeated in 1822 in the present territory of Colombia and in 1823 in Venezuela.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The territory of the Viceroyalty of New Granada became the
       <a href="/wiki/Gran_Colombia" title="Gran Colombia">
        Republic of Colombia
       </a>
       , organized as a
       <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Gran_Colombia" title="Subdivisions of Gran Colombia">
        union of the current territories
       </a>
       of Colombia, Panama, Ecuador, Venezuela, parts of Guyana and Brazil and north of
       <a href="/wiki/Mara%C3%B1%C3%B3n_River" title="Marañón River">
        Marañón River
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_C%C3%BAcuta" title="Congress of Cúcuta">
        Congress of Cúcuta
       </a>
       in 1821 adopted a
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Constitution_of_1821" title="Colombian Constitution of 1821">
        constitution
       </a>
       for the new Republic.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Simón Bolívar became the first
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Colombia" title="President of Colombia">
        President of Colombia
       </a>
       , and Francisco de Paula Santander was made
       <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_Colombia" title="Vice President of Colombia">
        Vice President
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, the new republic was unstable and three countries emerged from the collapse of
       <a href="/wiki/Gran_Colombia" title="Gran Colombia">
        Gran Colombia
       </a>
       in 1830 (New Granada, Ecuador and Venezuela).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EtHisColombia_86-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EtHisColombia-86">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GranColombiaNuevaGranada_87-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GranColombiaNuevaGranada-87">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1154" data-file-width="1082" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif/220px-Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif/330px-Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif/440px-Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Formation of the present Colombia since the
         <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada" title="Viceroyalty of New Granada">
          Viceroyalty of New Granada
         </a>
         's independence from the
         <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">
          Spanish Empire
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Colombia was the first
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitutional_government" title="Constitutional government">
        constitutional government
       </a>
       in South America,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HistoriaConstitucional_88-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HistoriaConstitucional-88">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Liberal_Party" title="Colombian Liberal Party">
        Liberal
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Conservative_Party" title="Colombian Conservative Party">
        Conservative
       </a>
       parties, founded in 1848 and 1849 respectively, are two of the oldest surviving
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_parties" title="Political parties">
        political parties
       </a>
       in the Americas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">
        Slavery
       </a>
       was abolished in the country in 1851.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
        <a href="#cite_note-91">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Internal political and territorial divisions led to the dissolution of
       <a href="/wiki/Gran_Colombia" title="Gran Colombia">
        Gran Colombia
       </a>
       in 1830.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EtHisColombia_86-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-EtHisColombia-86">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GranColombiaNuevaGranada_87-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-GranColombiaNuevaGranada-87">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The so-called "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cundinamarca_Province" title="Cundinamarca Province">
        Department of Cundinamarca
       </a>
       " adopted the name "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_the_New_Granada" title="Republic of the New Granada">
        New Granada
       </a>
       ", which it kept until 1858 when it became the "Confederación Granadina" (
       <a href="/wiki/Granadine_Confederation" title="Granadine Confederation">
        Granadine Confederation
       </a>
       ). After a
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Civil_War_(1860%E2%80%931862)" title="Colombian Civil War (1860–1862)">
        two-year civil war
       </a>
       in 1863, the "
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Colombia" title="United States of Colombia">
        United States of Colombia
       </a>
       " was created, lasting until 1886, when the country finally became known as the Republic of Colombia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HistoriaConstitucional_88-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-HistoriaConstitucional-88">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
        <a href="#cite_note-92">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Internal divisions remained between the bipartisan political forces, occasionally igniting very bloody civil wars, the most significant being the
       <a href="/wiki/Thousand_Days%27_War" title="Thousand Days' War">
        Thousand Days' War
       </a>
       (1899–1902).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="20th_century">
        20th century
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The United States of America's intentions to influence the area (especially the
       <a href="/wiki/Panama_Canal" title="Panama Canal">
        Panama Canal
       </a>
       construction and control) led to the
       <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_Panama_from_Colombia" title="Separation of Panama from Colombia">
        separation of the Department of Panama
       </a>
       in 1903 and the establishment of it as a nation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SeparationofPanama_94-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SeparationofPanama-94">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The United States paid Colombia $25,000,000 in 1921, seven years after completion of the canal, for redress of President
       <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Theodore Roosevelt">
        Roosevelt
       </a>
       's role in the creation of Panama, and Colombia recognized Panama under the terms of the
       <a href="/wiki/Thomson%E2%80%93Urrutia_Treaty" title="Thomson–Urrutia Treaty">
        Thomson–Urrutia Treaty
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia and Peru went to
       <a href="/wiki/Leticia_Incident" title="Leticia Incident">
        war
       </a>
       because of territory disputes far in the
       <a href="/wiki/Amazon_basin" title="Amazon basin">
        Amazon basin
       </a>
       . The war ended with a peace deal brokered by the
       <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">
        League of Nations
       </a>
       . The League finally awarded the disputed area to Colombia in June 1934.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
        <a href="#cite_note-96">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bogotazo.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="244" data-file-width="391" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Bogotazo.jpg/220px-Bogotazo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Bogotazo.jpg/330px-Bogotazo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/57/Bogotazo.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bogotazo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Bogotazo" title="Bogotazo">
          Bogotazo
         </a>
         in 1948
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Soon after, Colombia achieved some degree of political stability, which was interrupted by a bloody conflict that took place between the late 1940s and the early 1950s, a period known as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/La_Violencia" title="La Violencia">
         La Violencia
        </a>
       </i>
       ("The Violence"). Its cause was mainly mounting tensions between the two leading political parties, which subsequently ignited after the assassination of the Liberal presidential candidate
       <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Eli%C3%A9cer_Gait%C3%A1n" title="Jorge Eliécer Gaitán">
        Jorge Eliécer Gaitán
       </a>
       on 9 April 1948.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
        <a href="#cite_note-97">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The ensuing riots in Bogotá, known as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El_Bogotazo" title="El Bogotazo">
        El Bogotazo
       </a>
       , spread throughout the country and claimed the lives of at least 180,000 Colombians.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_99-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Encarta-99">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Colombia entered the
       <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">
        Korean War
       </a>
       when
       <a href="/wiki/Laureano_G%C3%B3mez" title="Laureano Gómez">
        Laureano Gómez
       </a>
       was elected president. It was the only Latin American country to join the war in a direct military role as an ally of the United States. Particularly important was the resistance of the Colombian troops at
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Old_Baldy" title="Battle of Old Baldy">
        Old Baldy
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombia's_legacy_with_Korea_100-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombia's_legacy_with_Korea-100">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The violence between the two political parties decreased first when
       <a href="/wiki/Gustavo_Rojas_Pinilla" title="Gustavo Rojas Pinilla">
        Gustavo Rojas
       </a>
       deposed the
       <a href="/wiki/Laureano_G%C3%B3mez" title="Laureano Gómez">
        President
       </a>
       of Colombia in a coup d'état and negotiated with the guerrillas, and then under the
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Military_Junta" title="Colombian Military Junta">
        military junta
       </a>
       of General
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gabriel_Par%C3%ADs" title="Gabriel París">
        Gabriel París
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
        <a href="#cite_note-102">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3134" data-file-width="4232" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg/220px-Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg/330px-Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg/440px-Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Axis of Peace and Memory: A "memorial" to the victims of the conflict
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       After Rojas' deposition, the Colombian Conservative Party and Colombian Liberal Party agreed to create the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Front_(Colombia)" title="National Front (Colombia)">
        National Front
       </a>
       , a coalition which would jointly govern the country. Under the deal, the presidency would alternate between conservatives and liberals every 4 years for 16 years; the two parties would have parity in all other elective offices.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The National Front ended "La Violencia", and National Front administrations attempted to institute far-reaching social and economic reforms in cooperation with the
       <a href="/wiki/Alliance_for_Progress" title="Alliance for Progress">
        Alliance for Progress
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
        <a href="#cite_note-105">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Despite the progress in certain sectors, many social and political problems continued, and guerrilla groups were formally created such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Revolutionary_Armed_Forces_of_Colombia" title="Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia">
        FARC
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Liberation_Army_(Colombia)" title="National Liberation Army (Colombia)">
        ELN
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/19th_of_April_Movement" title="19th of April Movement">
        M-19
       </a>
       to fight the government and political apparatus.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the 1960s, the country has suffered from an
       <a href="/wiki/Asymmetric_warfare" title="Asymmetric warfare">
        asymmetric
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Low_intensity_conflict" title="Low intensity conflict">
        low-intensity
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_armed_conflict_(1964%E2%80%93present)" title="Colombian armed conflict (1964–present)">
        armed conflict
       </a>
       between
       <a href="/wiki/Military_Forces_of_Colombia" title="Military Forces of Colombia">
        government forces
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Guerrilla_movements_in_Colombia" title="Guerrilla movements in Colombia">
        leftist guerrilla groups
       </a>
       and
