            </a>
           </td>
          </tr>
         </table>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Colombia" title="Economy of Colombia">
        Economy of Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Colombia" title="Agriculture in Colombia">
        Agriculture in Colombia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Industry_of_Colombia" title="Industry of Colombia">
        Industry of Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Colombia%27s_gross_domestic_product_by_sector_(2).png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="394" data-file-width="540" height="292" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Colombia%27s_gross_domestic_product_by_sector_%282%29.png/400px-Colombia%27s_gross_domestic_product_by_sector_%282%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d2/Colombia%27s_gross_domestic_product_by_sector_%282%29.png 1.5x" width="400"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Colombia%27s_gross_domestic_product_by_sector_(2).png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Colombia's gross domestic product by sector for the second half of the year 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Historically an agrarian economy, Colombia urbanised rapidly in the 20th century, by the end of which just 15.8% of the workforce were employed in agriculture, generating just 6.6% of GDP; 19.6% of the workforce were employed in industry and 64.6% in services, responsible for 33.4% and 59.9% of GDP respectively.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDP_Composition_190-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GDP_Composition-190">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Economic_production" title="Economic production">
        economic production
       </a>
       is dominated by its strong
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Domestic_demand" title="Domestic demand">
        domestic demand
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Consumer_spending" title="Consumer spending">
        Consumption expenditure
       </a>
       by households is the largest component of GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDPCOLOMBIA_192-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GDPCOLOMBIA-192">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDP_17-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-GDP-17">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombianeconomy_193-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombianeconomy-193">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Colombia's
       <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">
        market economy
       </a>
       grew steadily in the latter part of the 20th century, with gross domestic product (GDP) increasing at an average rate of over 4% per year between 1970 and 1998. The country suffered a
       <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">
        recession
       </a>
       in 1999 (the first full year of negative growth since the
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">
        Great Depression
       </a>
       ), and the recovery from that recession was long and painful. However, in recent years growth has been impressive, reaching 6.9% in 2007, one of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(real)_growth_rate" title="List of countries by GDP (real) growth rate">
        highest rates of growth
       </a>
       in Latin America.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombia's_GDP_growth_194-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombia's_GDP_growth-194">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">
        International Monetary Fund
       </a>
       estimates, in 2012 Colombia's GDP (PPP) was US$500 billion (
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">
        28th in the world
       </a>
       and third in South America).
      </p>
      <p>
       Total
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government_expenditures" title="Government expenditures">
        government expenditures
       </a>
       account for 27.9 percent of the domestic economy.
       <a href="/wiki/External_debt" title="External debt">
        External debt
       </a>
       equals 39.9 percent of gross domestic product. A strong fiscal climate was reaffirmed by a boost in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bond_ratings" title="Bond ratings">
        bond ratings
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-heritage_197-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-heritage-197">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Annual
       <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">
        inflation
       </a>
       closed 2017 at 4.09% YoY (vs. 5.75% YoY in 2016).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Inflation_Rate_198-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Inflation_Rate-198">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The average national
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unemployment_rate" title="Unemployment rate">
        unemployment rate
       </a>
       in 2017 was 9.4%,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unemployment_Rate_199-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Unemployment_Rate-199">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
       although the informality is the biggest problem facing the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labour_market" title="Labour market">
        labour market
       </a>
       (the income of formal workers climbed 24.8% in 5 years while labor incomes of informal workers rose only 9%).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-informal_workers_200-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-informal_workers-200">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia has
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_trade_Zone" title="Free trade Zone">
        Free trade Zone
       </a>
       (FTZ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FTZ_201-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FTZ-201">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       such as Zona Franca del Pacifico, located in the Valle del Cauca, one of the most striking areas for foreign investment.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zonas_Francas_202-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Zonas_Francas-202">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_sector" title="Financial sector">
        financial sector
       </a>
       has grown favorably due to good liquidity in the economy, the growth of credit and the positive performance of the Colombian economy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-strongpolicyframework_18-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-strongpolicyframework-18">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_Stock_Exchange" title="Colombian Stock Exchange">
        Colombian Stock Exchange
       </a>
       through the Latin American Integrated Market (
       <a href="/wiki/Mercado_Integrado_Latinoamericano" title="Mercado Integrado Latinoamericano">
        MILA
       </a>
       ) offers a regional market to trade equities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia is now one of only three economies with a perfect score on the strength of legal rights index, according to the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
        World Bank
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BVC_Bogota.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1460" data-file-width="928" height="267" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/BVC_Bogota.jpg/170px-BVC_Bogota.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/BVC_Bogota.jpg/255px-BVC_Bogota.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/BVC_Bogota.jpg/340px-BVC_Bogota.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BVC_Bogota.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_Stock_Exchange" title="Colombian Stock Exchange">
          Colombian Stock Exchange
         </a>
         is part of the Latin American Integrated Market (
         <a href="/wiki/Mercado_Integrado_Latinoamericano" title="Mercado Integrado Latinoamericano">
          MILA
         </a>
         ).
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MILA_208-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-MILA-208">
           [202]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The electricity production in Colombia comes mainly from
       <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">
        renewable energy sources
       </a>
       . 69.93% is obtained from the
       <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">
        hydroelectric generation
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
        <a href="#cite_note-209">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia's commitment to renewable energy was recognized in the 2014
       <i>
        Global Green Economy Index (GGEI)
       </i>
       , ranking among the top 10 nations in the world in terms of greening efficiency sectors.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ggei_210-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ggei-210">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Colombia is rich in natural resources, and its main exports include mineral fuels, oils,
       <a href="/wiki/Distillation#Industrial_distillation" title="Distillation">
        distillation products
       </a>
       , fruit and other agricultural products, sugars and sugar confectionery,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Food_products" title="Food products">
        food products
       </a>
       , plastics, precious stones, metals, forest products,
       <a href="/wiki/Chemical_industry" title="Chemical industry">
        chemical goods
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals" title="Pharmaceuticals">
        pharmaceuticals
       </a>
       , vehicles, electronic products, electrical equipments, perfumery and cosmetics, machinery, manufactured articles,
       <a href="/wiki/Textile" title="Textile">
        textile
       </a>
       and fabrics, clothing and footwear, glass and glassware, furniture, prefabricated buildings, military products, home and office material,
       <a href="/wiki/Construction" title="Construction">
        construction
       </a>
       equipment,
       <a href="/wiki/Software" title="Software">
        software
       </a>
       , among others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ITC_Colombia_Exports_211-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ITC_Colombia_Exports-211">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Principal trading partners are the United States, China, the European Union and some Latin American countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Exports_212-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Exports-212">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Imports_213-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Imports-213">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Non-traditional exports have boosted the growth of Colombian foreign sales as well as the diversification of destinations of export thanks to new
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_trade_agreements" title="Free trade agreements">
        free trade agreements
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2016, the National Administrative Department of Statistics (DANE) reported that 28.0% of the population were living below the poverty line, of which 8.5% in "extreme poverty". The multidimensional poverty rate stands at 17.8 percent of the population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-socio-economic_policies_5-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-socio-economic_policies-5">
         [5]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Government has also been developing a process of
       <a href="/wiki/Financial_inclusion" title="Financial inclusion">
        financial inclusion
       </a>
       within the country's most vulnerable population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Recent economic growth has led to a considerable increase of new millionaires, including the new entrepreneurs, Colombians with a net worth exceeding US $1 billion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
        <a href="#cite_note-216">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
        <a href="#cite_note-217">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The contribution of
       <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Colombia" title="Tourism in Colombia">
        Travel &amp; Tourism
       </a>
       to GDP was USD5,880.3bn (2.0% of total GDP) in 2016. Tourism generated 556,135 jobs (2.5% of total employment) in 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Foreign tourist visits were predicted to have risen from 0.6 million in 2007 to 3.3 million in 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
        <a href="#cite_note-219">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
        <a href="#cite_note-220">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">
        Science and technology
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Colombia" title="Science and technology in Colombia">
        Science and technology in Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Colciencias_271215.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Colciencias_271215.JPG/220px-Colciencias_271215.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Colciencias_271215.JPG/330px-Colciencias_271215.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Colciencias_271215.JPG/440px-Colciencias_271215.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Colciencias_271215.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/COLCIENCIAS" title="COLCIENCIAS">
          COLCIENCIAS
         </a>
         is a Colombian Government agency that supports fundamental and applied research.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Colombia has more than 3,950 research groups in science and technology.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
        <a href="#cite_note-221">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       iNNpulsa, a government body that promotes entrepreneurship and innovation in the country, provides grants to startups, in addition to other services it and institutions like Apps.co provide. Co-working spaces have arisen to serve as communities for startups large and small.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-venturebeat.com_222-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-venturebeat.com-222">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
        <a href="#cite_note-223">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Organizations such as the Corporation for Biological Research (CIB) for the support of young people interested in scientific work has been successfully developed in Colombia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
        <a href="#cite_note-224">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The International Center for Tropical Agriculture based in Colombia investigates the increasing challenge of
       <a href="/wiki/Global_warming" title="Global warming">
        global warming
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Food_security" title="Food security">
        food security
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
        <a href="#cite_note-225">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Important inventions related to the medicine have been made in Colombia, such as the first
       <a href="/wiki/Artificial_cardiac_pacemaker" title="Artificial cardiac pacemaker">
        external artificial pacemaker with internal electrodes
       </a>
       , invented by the electronics engineer
       <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Reynolds_Pombo" title="Jorge Reynolds Pombo">
        Jorge Reynolds Pombo
       </a>
       , invention of great importance for those who suffer from
       <a href="/wiki/Heart_failure" title="Heart failure">
        heart failure
       </a>
       . Also invented in Colombia were the
       <a href="/wiki/Microkeratome" title="Microkeratome">
        microkeratome
       </a>
       and keratomileusis technique, which form the fundamental basis of what now is known as
       <a href="/wiki/LASIK" title="LASIK">
        LASIK
       </a>
       (one of the most important techniques for the correction of
       <a href="/wiki/Refractive_error" title="Refractive error">
        refractive errors
       </a>
       of vision) and the
       <a href="/wiki/Salom%C3%B3n_Hakim#The_Invention_of_the_valve" title="Salomón Hakim">
        Hakim valve
       </a>
       for the treatment of
       <a href="/wiki/Hydrocephalus" title="Hydrocephalus">
        Hydrocephalus
       </a>
       , among others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
        <a href="#cite_note-226">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia has begun to innovate in military technology for its army and other armies of the world; especially in the design and creation of personal ballistic protection products, military hardware,
       <a href="/wiki/Military_robot" title="Military robot">
        military robots
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bomb" title="Bomb">
        bombs
       </a>
       , simulators and radar.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
        <a href="#cite_note-227">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
        <a href="#cite_note-229">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some leading Colombian scientists are Joseph M. Tohme, researcher recognized for his work on the
       <a href="/wiki/Genetic_diversity" title="Genetic diversity">
        genetic diversity
       </a>
       of food, Manuel Elkin Patarroyo who is known for his groundbreaking work on
       <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_vaccine" title="Synthetic vaccine">
        synthetic vaccines
       </a>
       for
       <a href="/wiki/Malaria" title="Malaria">
        malaria
       </a>
       , Francisco Lopera who discovered the "Paisa Mutation" or a type of
       <a href="/wiki/Early-onset_Alzheimer%27s_disease" title="Early-onset Alzheimer's disease">
        early-onset Alzheimer's
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Francisco_Lopera_230-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Francisco_Lopera-230">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Rodolfo_Llin%C3%A1s" title="Rodolfo Llinás">
        Rodolfo Llinás
       </a>
       known for his study of the intrinsic
       <a href="/wiki/Neuron" title="Neuron">
        neurons
       </a>
       properties and the theory of a syndrome that had changed the way of understanding the functioning of the brain, Jairo Quiroga Puello recognized for his studies on the characterization of
       <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_substance" title="Synthetic substance">
        synthetic substances
       </a>
       which can be used to fight
       <a href="/wiki/Fungus" title="Fungus">
        fungus
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tumor" title="Tumor">
        tumors
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tuberculosis" title="Tuberculosis">
        tuberculosis
       </a>
       and even some
       <a href="/wiki/Virus" title="Virus">
        viruses
       </a>
       and Ángela Restrepo who established accurate
       <a href="/wiki/Medical_diagnosis" title="Medical diagnosis">
        diagnoses
       </a>
       and treatments to combat the effects of a disease caused by the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Paracoccidioides_brasiliensis" title="Paracoccidioides brasiliensis">
         Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
        </a>
       </i>
       , among other
       <a href="/wiki/Scientist" title="Scientist">
        scientists
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Científicos_colombianos_231-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Científicos_colombianos-231">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brillantes_colombianos_232-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-brillantes_colombianos-232">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Científicos_destacados_233-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Científicos_destacados-233">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">
        Infrastructure
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Colombia" title="Transport in Colombia">
        Transport in Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg/190px-Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg/285px-Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg/380px-Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg 2x" width="190"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Port of
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cartagena_de_Indias" title="Cartagena de Indias">
          Cartagena
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Transportation in Colombia is regulated within the functions of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Transport_(Colombia)" title="Ministry of Transport (Colombia)">
        Ministry of Transport
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTransport_234-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MTransport-234">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and entities such as the National Roads Institute (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INV%C3%8DAS" title="INVÍAS">
        INVÍAS
       </a>
       ) responsible for the
       <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Colombia" title="Highways in Colombia">
        Highways in Colombia
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
        <a href="#cite_note-235">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aerocivil" title="Aerocivil">
        Aerocivil
       </a>
       , responsible for civil aviation and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Colombia" title="List of airports in Colombia">
        airports
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
        <a href="#cite_note-236">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Infrastructure_Agency_(Colombia)" title="National Infrastructure Agency (Colombia)">
        National Infrastructure Agency
       </a>
       , in charge of
       <a href="/wiki/Concession_(contract)" title="Concession (contract)">
        concessions
       </a>
       through
       <a href="/wiki/Public%E2%80%93private_partnership" title="Public–private partnership">
        public–private partnerships
       </a>
       , for the design, construction, maintenance, operation, and administration of the transport infrastructure,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
        <a href="#cite_note-237">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the General Maritime Directorate (Dimar) has the responsibility of coordinating maritime traffic control along with the Colombian Navy,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
        <a href="#cite_note-238">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
       among others and under the supervision of the
       <a href="/wiki/Superintendency_of_Ports_and_Transport_(Colombia)" title="Superintendency of Ports and Transport (Colombia)">
        Superintendency of Ports and Transport
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
        <a href="#cite_note-239">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The road network in Colombia has a length of about 215,000 km of which 23,000 are paved.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transporte_240-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-transporte-240">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Colombia" title="Rail transport in Colombia">
        Rail transportation
       </a>
       in Colombia is dedicated almost entirely to
       <a href="/wiki/Rail_freight_transport" title="Rail freight transport">
        freight shipments
       </a>
       and the railway network has a length of 1,700 km of potentially active rails.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transporte_240-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-transporte-240">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia has 3,960 kilometers of gas pipelines, 4,900 kilometers of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oil_pipelines" title="Oil pipelines">
        oil pipelines
       </a>
       , and 2,990 kilometers of refined-products pipelines.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transporte_240-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-transporte-240">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The target of Colombia's government is to build 7,000 km of roads for the 2016–2020 period and reduce travel times by 30 per cent and transport costs by 20 per cent. A toll road concession programme will comprise 40 projects, and is part of a larger strategic goal to invest nearly $50bn in transport infrastructure, including: railway systems; making the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magdalena_river" title="Magdalena river">
        Magdalena river
       </a>
       navigable again; improving port facilities; as well as an expansion of
       <a href="/wiki/El_Dorado_International_Airport" title="El Dorado International Airport">
        Bogotá's airport
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Colombia" title="Demographics of Colombia">
        Demographics of Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Colombian_Departments_by_population" title="List of Colombian Departments by population">
        List of Colombian Departments by population
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1395" data-file-width="1167" height="299" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png/250px-Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png/375px-Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png/500px-Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Population density of Colombia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       With an estimated 49 million people in 2017, Colombia is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">
        third-most populous country
       </a>
       in Latin America, after Brazil and Mexico.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DANE_clock_3-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-DANE_clock-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is also home to the third-largest number of
       <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone" title="Hispanophone">
        Spanish speakers
       </a>
       in the world after Mexico and the United States.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
        <a href="#cite_note-242">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At the beginning of the 20th century, Colombia's population was approximately 4 million.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
        <a href="#cite_note-243">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since the early 1970s Colombia has experienced steady declines in its fertility, mortality, and
       <a href="/wiki/Population_growth" title="Population growth">
        population growth
       </a>
       rates. The population growth rate for 2016 is estimated to be 0.9%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population_growth_244-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Population_growth-244">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">
        total fertility rate
       </a>
       was 1.9 births per woman in 2015.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Total_fertility_rate_245-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Total_fertility_rate-245">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
       About 26.8% of the population were 15 years old or younger, 65.7% were between 15 and 64 years old, and 7.4% were over 65 years old. The proportion of older persons in the total population has begun to increase substantially.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
        <a href="#cite_note-246">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia is projected to have a population of 50.2 million by 2020 and 55.3 million by 2050.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
        <a href="#cite_note-247">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The population is concentrated in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Andean_Region_of_Colombia" title="Andean Region of Colombia">
        Andean highlands
       </a>
       and along the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caribbean_Region_of_Colombia" title="Caribbean Region of Colombia">
        Caribbean coast
       </a>
       , also the population densities are generally higher in the Andean region. The nine eastern lowland departments, comprising about 54% of Colombia's area, have less than 6% of the population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-populationbyregions_141-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-populationbyregions-141">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population_density_142-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Population_density-142">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Traditionally a rural society,
       <a href="/wiki/Urbanization" title="Urbanization">
        movement to urban areas
       </a>
       was very heavy in the mid-20th century, and Colombia is now one of the most urbanized countries in Latin America. The urban population increased from 31% of the total in 1938 to nearly 60% in 1973, and by 2014 the figure stood at 76%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Country_Study_248-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Country_Study-248">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
        <a href="#cite_note-249">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The population of
       <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">
        Bogotá
       </a>
       alone has increased from just over 300,000 in 1938 to approximately 8 million today.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
        <a href="#cite_note-250">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In total seventy-two cities now have populations of 100,000 or more (2015).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Largest_cities_or_towns_251-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Largest_cities_or_towns-251">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2012
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Colombia&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia has the world's largest populations of
       <a href="/wiki/Internally_displaced_person" title="Internally displaced person">
        internally displaced persons
       </a>
       (IDPs), estimated to be up to 4.9 million people.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNHCR_252-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNHCR-252">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The life expectancy is 74.8 years in 2015 and infant mortality is 13.1 per thousand in 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Life_expectancy_at_birth_253-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Life_expectancy_at_birth-253">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infant_mortality_254-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-infant_mortality-254">
         [248]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2015, 94.58% of adults and 98.66% of youth are literate and the government spends about 4.49% of its GDP in education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNESCO_255-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNESCO-255">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Colombia is ranked third in the world in the
       <a href="/wiki/Happy_Planet_Index" title="Happy Planet Index">
        Happy Planet Index
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
        Languages
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Colombia" title="Languages of Colombia">
        Languages of Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Spanish" title="Colombian Spanish">
        Colombian Spanish
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       More than 99.2% of Colombians speak
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish
       </a>
       , also called Castilian; 65
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amerindian_language" title="Amerindian language">
        Amerindian languages
       </a>
       , two
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Creole_languages" title="Creole languages">
        Creole languages
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">
        Romani language
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Sign_Language" title="Colombian Sign Language">
        Colombian Sign Language
       </a>
       are also spoken in the country.
       <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
        English
       </a>
       has official status in the
       <a href="/wiki/Archipelago_of_San_Andr%C3%A9s,_Providencia_and_Santa_Catalina" title="Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina">
        archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LEY47DE1993_8-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-LEY47DE1993-8">
         [8]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lenguas_indígenas_256-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-lenguas_indígenas-256">
         [250]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Languages_of_Colombia_257-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Languages_of_Colombia-257">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MapofthelanguagesofColombia_258-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MapofthelanguagesofColombia-258">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Including Spanish, a total of 101 languages are listed for Colombia in the
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">
        Ethnologue
       </a>
       database. The specific number of spoken languages varies slightly since some authors consider as different languages what others consider to be varieties or dialects of the same language. Best estimates recorded 71 languages that are spoken in-country today—most of which belong to the
       <a href="/wiki/Chibchan_languages" title="Chibchan languages">
        Chibchan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tucanoan_languages" title="Tucanoan languages">
        Tucanoan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bora%E2%80%93Witoto_languages" title="Bora–Witoto languages">
        Bora–Witoto
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Guajiboan_languages" title="Guajiboan languages">
        Guajiboan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Arawakan_languages" title="Arawakan languages">
        Arawakan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cariban_languages" title="Cariban languages">
        Cariban
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Barbacoan_languages" title="Barbacoan languages">
        Barbacoan
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Piaroa%E2%80%93Saliban_languages" title="Piaroa–Saliban languages">
        Saliban
       </a>
       language families. There are currently about 850,000 speakers of native languages.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnologue_259-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ethnologue-259">
         [253]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nativelanguages_260-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nativelanguages-260">
         [254]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">
        Ethnic groups
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="barbox tleft" style="overflow-x: auto;">
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;">
        <table style="border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
         <tr style="background:#AAF">
          <th colspan="5">
           Human biological diversity and ethnicity
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grupos_étnicos_1-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-grupos_étnicos-1">
             [1]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Society_and_Its_Environment_2-1">
            <a href="#cite_note-The_Society_and_Its_Environment-2">
             [2]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </th>
         </tr>
         <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
          <td style="padding:0 4px;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="width:100px;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
           Percentage
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mestizo_Colombian" title="Mestizo Colombian">
            Mestizo
           </a>
           and
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_Colombian" title="White Colombian">
            White
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:#008080; width:86%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           86%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afro-Colombian" title="Afro-Colombian">
            Black
           </a>
           (includes
           <a href="/wiki/Mulatto" title="Mulatto">
            Mulatto
           </a>
           )
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:#FFBF00; width:10.6%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           10.6%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">
            Amerindian
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:#1C39BB; width:3.4%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           3.4%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">
            Roma
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:#000000; width:0.01%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.01%
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_Colombia" title="Race and ethnicity in Colombia">
        Human biological diversity and ethnicity in Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Colombia is ethnically diverse, its people descending from the original
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">
        native
       </a>
       inhabitants,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_people" title="Spanish people">
        Spanish
       </a>
       colonists,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_Colombian" title="African Colombian">
        Africans
       </a>
       originally brought to the country as slaves, and 20th-century
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_diaspora" title="European diaspora">
        immigrants from Europe
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Arab_Colombians" title="Arab Colombians">
        Middle East
       </a>
       , all contributing to a diverse cultural heritage.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombia_is_ethnically_diverse_261-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombia_is_ethnically_diverse-261">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The demographic distribution reflects a pattern that is influenced by colonial history.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
        <a href="#cite_note-262">
         [256]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Whites tend to live mainly in urban centers, like
       <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">
        Bogotá
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Medell%C3%ADn" title="Medellín">
        Medellín
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Cali" title="Cali">
        Cali
       </a>
       , and the burgeoning highland cities. The populations of the major cities also include mestizos.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mestizo_Colombian" title="Mestizo Colombian">
        Mestizo
       </a>
       <i>
        campesinos
       </i>
       (people living in rural areas) also live in the Andean highlands where some Spanish conquerors mixed with the women of Amerindian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chiefdoms" title="Chiefdoms">
        chiefdoms
       </a>
       . Mestizos include artisans and small tradesmen that have played a major part in the urban expansion of recent decades.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
        <a href="#cite_note-263">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The 2005 census reported that the "non-ethnic population", consisting of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_Colombian" title="White Colombian">
        whites
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mestizo_Colombian" title="Mestizo Colombian">
        mestizos
       </a>
       (those of mixed white European and Amerindian ancestry), constituted 86% of the national population. 10.6% is of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afro-Colombian" title="Afro-Colombian">
        African
       </a>
       ancestry.
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">
        Indigenous Amerindians
       </a>
       comprise 3.4% of the population. 0.01% of the population are
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">
        Roma
       </a>
       . An extraofficial estimate considers that the 49% of the Colombian population is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mestizo_Colombian" title="Mestizo Colombian">
        Mestizo
       </a>
       or of mixed European and Amerindian ancestry, and that approximately 37% is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_Colombian" title="White Colombian">
        White
       </a>
       , mainly of
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_immigration_to_Colombia" title="Spanish immigration to Colombia">
        Spanish
       </a>
       lineage, but there is also a large population of
       <a href="/wiki/Arab_Colombians" title="Arab Colombians">
        Middle East
       </a>
       descent; in some sectors of society there is a considerable input of
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_Colombian" title="Italian Colombian">
        Italian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/German_Colombian" title="German Colombian">
        German
       </a>
       ancestry.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Society_and_Its_Environment_2-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_Society_and_Its_Environment-2">
         [2]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:308px;max-width:308px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mapa_de_Colombia_(poblaci%C3%B3n_afrodescendiente_2005).svg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="5050" data-file-width="3731" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_afrodescendiente_2005%29.svg/150px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_afrodescendiente_2005%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_afrodescendiente_2005%29.svg/225px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_afrodescendiente_2005%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_afrodescendiente_2005%29.svg/300px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_afrodescendiente_2005%29.svg.png 2x" width="150"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          People with
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_Colombian" title="African Colombian">
           African ancestry
          </a>
          in Colombia are concentrated mostly in coastal areas.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mapa_de_Colombia_(poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005).svg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="5050" data-file-width="3731" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg/150px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg/225px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg/300px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg.png 2x" width="150"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">
           Amerindian
          </a>
          population of Colombia by municipality in 2005.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Many of the
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">
        Indigenous peoples
       </a>
       experienced a reduction in population during the Spanish rule
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
        <a href="#cite_note-264">
         [258]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and many others were absorbed into the mestizo population, but the remainder currently represents over eighty distinct cultures. Reserves (
       <i>
        resguardos
       </i>
       ) established for indigenous peoples occupy 30,571,640 hectares (305,716.4 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       ) (27% of the country's total) and are inhabited by more than 800,000 people.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Resguardos_Indígenas_265-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Resguardos_Indígenas-265">
         [259]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some of the largest indigenous groups are the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wayuu" title="Wayuu">
        Wayuu
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wayuu_266-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-wayuu-266">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Paez_people" title="Paez people">
        Paez
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Pastos_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pastos people (page does not exist)">
        Pastos
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ember%C3%A1_people" title="Emberá people">
        Emberá
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Zen%C3%BA" title="Zenú">
        Zenú
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pueblos_indígenas_267-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pueblos_indígenas-267">
         [261]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The departments of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_of_La_Guajira" title="Department of La Guajira">
        La Guajira
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cauca_Department" title="Cauca Department">
        Cauca
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Nari%C3%B1o_Department" title="Nariño Department">
        Nariño
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba_Department" title="Córdoba Department">
        Córdoba
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sucre_Department" title="Sucre Department">
        Sucre
       </a>
       have the largest indigenous populations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grupos_étnicos_1-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-grupos_étnicos-1">
         [1]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/National_Indigenous_Organization_of_Colombia" title="National Indigenous Organization of Colombia">
        Organización Nacional Indígena de Colombia
       </a>
       (ONIC), founded at the first National Indigenous Congress in 1982, is an organization representing the indigenous peoples of Colombia. In 1991, Colombia signed and ratified the current international law concerning indigenous peoples,
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_and_Tribal_Peoples_Convention,_1989" title="Indigenous and Tribal Peoples Convention, 1989">
        Indigenous and Tribal Peoples Convention, 1989
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ratifications_-_ilo.org_268-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ratifications_-_ilo.org-268">
         [262]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa" title="Ethnic groups of Africa">
        Black Africans
       </a>
       were brought as
       <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">
        slaves
       </a>
       , mostly to the coastal lowlands, beginning early in the 16th century and continuing into the 19th century. Large Afro-Colombian communities are found today on the Caribbean and Pacific coasts. The population of the
       <a href="/wiki/Choc%C3%B3_Department" title="Chocó Department">
        department of Chocó
       </a>
       , running along the northern portion of Colombia's Pacific coast, is over 80% black.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grupos_Étnicos_269-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Grupos_Étnicos-269">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/British_people" title="British people">
        British
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jamaican_people" title="Jamaican people">
        Jamaicans
       </a>
       migrated mainly to the islands of San Andres and Providencia. A number of other Europeans and North Americans migrated to the country in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including people from the former
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USSR" title="USSR">
        USSR
       </a>
       during and after the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">
        Second World War
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Extranjeros_en_Colombia_270-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Extranjeros_en_Colombia-270">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Migraciones_Internacionales_271-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Migraciones_Internacionales-271">
         [265]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Many immigrant communities have settled on the Caribbean coast, in particular recent immigrants from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_West_Asia" title="Ethnic groups in West Asia">
        Middle East
       </a>
       . Barranquilla (the largest city of the Colombian Caribbean) and other Caribbean cities have the largest populations of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lebanese_Colombian" title="Lebanese Colombian">
        Lebanese
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palestinian_people" title="Palestinian people">
        Palestinian
       </a>
       , and other
       <a href="/wiki/Arab_Colombians" title="Arab Colombians">
        Arabs
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arab_colombians_272-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-arab_colombians-272">
         [266]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
        <a href="#cite_note-273">
         [267]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are also important communities of
       <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people" title="Chinese people">
        Chinese
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_Colombian" title="Japanese Colombian">
        Japanese
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">
        Romanis
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Colombia" title="History of the Jews in Colombia">
        Jews
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombia_is_ethnically_diverse_261-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombia_is_ethnically_diverse-261">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There is a major migration trend of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Venezuelan_people" title="Venezuelan people">
        Venezuelans
       </a>
       , due to the political and economic situation in Venezuela.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
        <a href="#cite_note-274">
         [268]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Colombia" title="Religion in Colombia">
        Religion in Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Colombia" title="Freedom of religion in Colombia">
        Freedom of religion in Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Santuario_de_Las_Lajas,_Ipiales,_Colombia,_2015-07-21,_DD_21-23_HDR-Edit.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2758" data-file-width="3958" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR-Edit.JPG/220px-Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR-Edit.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR-Edit.JPG/330px-Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR-Edit.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR-Edit.JPG/440px-Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR-Edit.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Santuario_de_Las_Lajas,_Ipiales,_Colombia,_2015-07-21,_DD_21-23_HDR-Edit.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Las_Lajas_Sanctuary" title="Las Lajas Sanctuary">
          Las Lajas Sanctuary
         </a>
         in the southern Colombian Department of
         <a href="/wiki/Nari%C3%B1o_Department" title="Nariño Department">
          Nariño
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Administrative_Department_of_Statistics" title="National Administrative Department of Statistics">
        National Administrative Department of Statistics
       </a>
       (DANE) does not collect religious statistics, and accurate reports are difficult to obtain. However, based on various studies and a survey, about 90% of the population adheres to
       <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
        Christianity
       </a>
       , the majority of which (70.9%) are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" title="Roman Catholic">
        Roman Catholic
       </a>
       , while a significant minority (16.7%) adhere to
       <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">
        Protestantism
       </a>
       (primarily
       <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">
        Evangelicalism
       </a>
       ). Some 4.7% of the population is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheist" title="Atheist">
        atheist
       </a>
       or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agnostic" title="Agnostic">
        agnostic
       </a>
       , while 3.5% claim to believe in God but do not follow a specific religion. 1.8% of Colombians adhere to
       <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">
        Jehovah's Witnesses
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Adventism" title="Adventism">
        Adventism
       </a>
       and less than 1% adhere to other religions, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
        Islam
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">
        Judaism
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">
        Buddhism
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mormonism" title="Mormonism">
        Mormonism
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">
        Hinduism
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Animism" title="Animism">
        Indigenous religions
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hare_Krishna_movement" title="Hare Krishna movement">
        Hare Krishna movement
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rastafari_movement" title="Rastafari movement">
        Rastafari movement
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orthodox_Catholic_Church" title="Orthodox Catholic Church">
        Orthodox Catholic Church
       </a>
       , and spiritual studies. The remaining people either did not respond or replied that they did not know. In addition to the above statistics, 35.9% of Colombians reported that they did not practice their faith actively.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Religion_275-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Religion-275">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Religion2_276-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Religion2-276">
         [270]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Religion_in_Latin_America_277-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Religion_in_Latin_America-277">
         [271]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       While Colombia remains a mostly Roman Catholic country by
       <a href="/wiki/Baptism" title="Baptism">
        baptism
       </a>
       numbers, the 1991 Colombian constitution guarantees freedom of religion and all religious faiths and churches are equally free before the law.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278">
        <a href="#cite_note-278">
         [272]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Largest_cities">
        Largest cities
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Colombia is a highly urbanized country. The largest cities in the country are
       <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">
        Bogotá
       </a>
       , with an estimated 8 million inhabitants,
       <a href="/wiki/Medell%C3%ADn" title="Medellín">
        Medellín
       </a>
       , with an estimated 2.5 million inhabitants,
       <a href="/wiki/Cali" title="Cali">
        Cali
       </a>
       , with an estimated 2.4 million inhabitants, and
       <a href="/wiki/Barranquilla" title="Barranquilla">
        Barranquilla
       </a>
       , with an estimated 1.2 million inhabitants.
       <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">
        Cartagena
       </a>
       highlights in number of inhabitants and the city of
       <a href="/wiki/Bucaramanga" title="Bucaramanga">
        Bucaramanga
       </a>
       is relevant in terms of
       <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_of_Colombia" title="Metropolitan areas of Colombia">
        metropolitan area population
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Largest_cities_or_towns_251-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Largest_cities_or_towns-251">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="navbox">
       <tr>
        <th class="navbox-title" colspan="10">
         <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">
         </div>
         <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="float: left;height:2.6em;">
          <ul>
           <li class="nv-view">

             <abbr title="View this template">
              v
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-talk">
            <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Largest_cities_of_Colombia" title="Template talk:Largest cities of Colombia">
             <abbr title="Discuss this template">
              t
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-edit">
            <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_of_Colombia&amp;action=edit">
             <abbr title="Edit this template">
              e
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;">
          <span style="font-size:110%;">
           Largest cities or towns in Colombia
          </span>
          <br/>
          <span style="font-weight:normal;">
           <a href="/wiki/National_Administrative_Department_of_Statistics_(Colombia)" title="National Administrative Department of Statistics (Colombia)">
            National Administrative Department of Statistics
           </a>
           (DANE), 2016 projections
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Largest_cities_or_towns_251-2">
            <a href="#cite_note-Largest_cities_or_towns-251">
             [245]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </div>
        </th>
       </tr>

         </a>
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">
          Bogotá
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:El_poblado,_Medell%C3%ADn.jpg" title="Medellín">
          <img alt="Medellín" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2323" data-file-width="3485" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/El_poblado%2C_Medell%C3%ADn.jpg/120px-El_poblado%2C_Medell%C3%ADn.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/El_poblado%2C_Medell%C3%ADn.jpg/180px-El_poblado%2C_Medell%C3%ADn.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/El_poblado%2C_Medell%C3%ADn.jpg/240px-El_poblado%2C_Medell%C3%ADn.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/Medell%C3%ADn" title="Medellín">
          Medellín
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
         1
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">
          Bogotá
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">
          Bogotá
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:right;">
         7,963,379
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
         11
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a href="/wiki/Santa_Marta" title="Santa Marta">

         </a>
        </td>

         474,520
        </td>
        <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Santiago_de_Cali.jpg" title="Cali">

        </td>
