        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Culture_of_Colombia" title="Culture of Colombia">
        Culture of Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Festivals_in_Colombia" title="Festivals in Colombia">
        Festivals in Colombia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_folklore" title="Colombian folklore">
        Colombian folklore
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Colombia lies at the crossroads of
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_culture" title="Latin American culture">
        Latin America
       </a>
       and the broader American continent, and as such has been hit by a wide range of cultural influences.
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">
        Native American
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Spain" title="Culture of Spain">
        Spanish
       </a>
       and other
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Europe" title="Culture of Europe">
        European
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Africa" title="Culture of Africa">
        African
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States" title="Culture of the United States">
        American
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Caribbean" title="Culture of the Caribbean">
        Caribbean
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Arab_culture" title="Arab culture">
        Middle Eastern
       </a>
       influences, as well as other Latin American cultural influences, are all present in Colombia's modern culture. Urban migration, industrialization, globalization, and other political, social and economic changes have also left an impression.
      </p>
      <p>
       Many
       <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Colombia" title="National symbols of Colombia">
        national symbols
       </a>
       , both objects and themes, have arisen from Colombia's diverse cultural traditions and aim to represent what Colombia, and the Colombian people, have in common. Cultural expressions in Colombia are promoted by the government through the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(Colombia)" title="Ministry of Culture (Colombia)">
        Ministry of Culture
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">
        Literature
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_literature" title="Colombian literature">
        Colombian literature
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez,_2009.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1658" data-file-width="1820" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg/220px-Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg/330px-Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg/440px-Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez,_2009.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_in_Literature" title="List of Nobel laureates in Literature">
          Nobel literature
         </a>
         prize winner
         <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Garc%C3%ADa_M%C3%A1rquez" title="Gabriel García Márquez">
          Gabriel García Márquez
         </a>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
          <a href="#cite_note-279">
           [273]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fi_322_Isaacs,_Jorge.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="943" data-file-width="655" height="245" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Fi_322_Isaacs%2C_Jorge.jpg/170px-Fi_322_Isaacs%2C_Jorge.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Fi_322_Isaacs%2C_Jorge.jpg/255px-Fi_322_Isaacs%2C_Jorge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Fi_322_Isaacs%2C_Jorge.jpg/340px-Fi_322_Isaacs%2C_Jorge.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fi_322_Isaacs,_Jorge.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Isaacs" title="Jorge Isaacs">
          Jorge Isaacs
         </a>
         was one of the greatest exponents of Colombian literature in the nineteenth century.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Colombian literature dates back to pre-Columbian era; a notable example of the period is the epic poem known as the
       <i>
        Legend of Yurupary
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Legend_of_Yurupary_280-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_Legend_of_Yurupary-280">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In Spanish colonial times, notable writers include
       <a href="/wiki/Juan_de_Castellanos" title="Juan de Castellanos">
        Juan de Castellanos
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Eleg%C3%ADas_de_varones_ilustres_de_Indias" title="Elegías de varones ilustres de Indias">
         Elegías de varones ilustres de Indias
        </a>
       </i>
       ), Hernando Domínguez Camargo and his epic poem to San Ignacio de Loyola,
       <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Sim%C3%B3n" title="Pedro Simón">
        Pedro Simón
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Juan_Rodr%C3%ADguez_Freyle" title="Juan Rodríguez Freyle">
        Juan Rodríguez Freyle
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/El_Carnero" title="El Carnero">
         El Carnero
        </a>
       </i>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281">
        <a href="#cite_note-281">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Lucas_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Piedrahita" title="Lucas Fernández de Piedrahita">
        Lucas Fernández de Piedrahita
       </a>
       , and the nun
       <a href="/wiki/Francisca_Josefa_de_la_Concepci%C3%B3n" title="Francisca Josefa de la Concepción">
        Francisca Josefa de Castillo
       </a>
       , representative of
       <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">
        mysticism
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Post-independence literature linked to Romanticism highlighted
       <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Nari%C3%B1o" title="Antonio Nariño">
        Antonio Nariño
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Fern%C3%A1ndez_Madrid" title="José Fernández Madrid">
        José Fernández Madrid
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Camilo_Torres_Tenorio" title="Camilo Torres Tenorio">
        Camilo Torres Tenorio
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Antonio_Zea" title="Francisco Antonio Zea">
        Francisco Antonio Zea
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
        <a href="#cite_note-282">
         [276]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
        <a href="#cite_note-283">
         [277]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the second half of the nineteenth century and early twentieth century the literary genre known as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Costumbrismo" title="Costumbrismo">
         costumbrismo
        </a>
       </i>
       became popular; great writers of this period were
       <a href="/wiki/Tom%C3%A1s_Carrasquilla" title="Tomás Carrasquilla">
        Tomás Carrasquilla
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Isaacs" title="Jorge Isaacs">
        Jorge Isaacs
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Pombo" title="Rafael Pombo">
        Rafael Pombo
       </a>
       (the latter of whom wrote notable works of children's literature).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
        <a href="#cite_note-284">
         [278]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285">
        <a href="#cite_note-285">
         [279]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Within that period, authors such as
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Asunci%C3%B3n_Silva" title="José Asunción Silva">
        José Asunción Silva
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Eustasio_Rivera" title="José Eustasio Rivera">
        José Eustasio Rivera
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_de_Greiff" title="León de Greiff">
        León de Greiff
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_Barba-Jacob" title="Porfirio Barba-Jacob">
        Porfirio Barba-Jacob
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Vargas_Vila" title="José María Vargas Vila">
        José María Vargas Vila
       </a>
       developed the
       <a href="/wiki/Modernismo" title="Modernismo">
        modernist
       </a>
       movement.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286">
        <a href="#cite_note-286">
         [280]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287">
        <a href="#cite_note-287">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288">
        <a href="#cite_note-288">
         [282]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1872, Colombia established the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_Academy_of_Language" title="Colombian Academy of Language">
        Colombian Academy of Language
       </a>
       , the first Spanish language academy in the Americas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
        <a href="#cite_note-289">
         [283]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Candelario Obeso wrote the groundbreaking
       <i>
        Cantos Populares de mi Tierra
       </i>
       (1877), the first book of poetry by an Afro-Colombian author.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
        <a href="#cite_note-290">
         [284]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Candelario_Obeso_291-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Candelario_Obeso-291">
         [285]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Between 1939 and 1940 seven books of poetry were published under the name
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Stone_and_Sky_(movement)" title="Stone and Sky (movement)">
         Stone and Sky
        </a>
       </i>
       in the city of Bogotá that significantly impacted the country; they were edited by the poet Jorge Rojas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
        <a href="#cite_note-292">
         [286]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the following decade,
       <a href="/wiki/Gonzalo_Arango" title="Gonzalo Arango">
        Gonzalo Arango
       </a>
       founded the movement of "
       <a href="/wiki/Nadaism" title="Nadaism">
        nothingness
       </a>
       " in response to the violence of the time;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
        <a href="#cite_note-293">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
       he was influenced by
       <a href="/wiki/Nihilism" title="Nihilism">
        nihilism
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Existentialism" title="Existentialism">
        existentialism
       </a>
       , and the thought of another great Colombian writer:
       <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Gonz%C3%A1lez_(writer)" title="Fernando González (writer)">
        Fernando González Ochoa
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
        <a href="#cite_note-294">
         [288]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Boom" title="Latin American Boom">
        boom in Latin American literature
       </a>
       , successful writers emerged, led by
       <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">
        Nobel laureate
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Garc%C3%ADa_M%C3%A1rquez" title="Gabriel García Márquez">
        Gabriel García Márquez
       </a>
       and his magnum opus,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/One_Hundred_Years_of_Solitude" title="One Hundred Years of Solitude">
         One Hundred Years of Solitude
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Caballero_Calder%C3%B3n" title="Eduardo Caballero Calderón">
        Eduardo Caballero Calderón
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Mej%C3%ADa_Vallejo" title="Manuel Mejía Vallejo">
        Manuel Mejía Vallejo
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Mutis" title="Álvaro Mutis">
        Álvaro Mutis
       </a>
       , a writer who was awarded the
       <a href="/wiki/Miguel_de_Cervantes_Prize" title="Miguel de Cervantes Prize">
        Cervantes Prize
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince_of_Asturias_Award_for_Letters" title="Prince of Asturias Award for Letters">
        Prince of Asturias Award for Letters
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
        <a href="#cite_note-295">
         [289]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
        <a href="#cite_note-296">
         [290]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other leading contemporary authors are
       <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Vallejo" title="Fernando Vallejo">
        Fernando Vallejo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/William_Ospina" title="William Ospina">
        William Ospina
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B3mulo_Gallegos_Prize" title="Rómulo Gallegos Prize">
        Rómulo Gallegos Prize
       </a>
       ) and
       <a href="/wiki/Germ%C3%A1n_Castro_Caycedo" title="Germán Castro Caycedo">
        Germán Castro Caycedo
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">
        Visual arts
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_art" title="Colombian art">
        Colombian art
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Monumento_pantano_de_vargas,_completo._2006.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG/220px-Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG/330px-Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG/440px-Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Monumento_pantano_de_vargas,_completo._2006.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Vargas_Swamp_Lancers" title="Vargas Swamp Lancers">
          Vargas Swamp Lancers
         </a>
         , artwork by
         <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Arenas_Betancourt" title="Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt">
          Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:184px;max-width:184px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:182px;max-width:182px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2136" data-file-width="2965" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg/180px-AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg/270px-AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg/360px-AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Work of the painter, and sculptor
          <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Botero" title="Fernando Botero">
           Fernando Botero
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:182px;max-width:182px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="275" data-file-width="330" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg/180px-Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg/270px-Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/28/Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Mural by
          <a href="/wiki/Santiago_Mart%C3%ADnez_Delgado" title="Santiago Martínez Delgado">
           Santiago Martínez Delgado
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Colombian art has over 3,000 years of history. Colombian artists have captured the country's changing political and cultural backdrop using a range of styles and mediums. There is archeological evidence of ceramics being produced earlier in Colombia than anywhere else in the Americas, dating as early as 3,000 BCE.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-donquijote.org_297-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-donquijote.org-297">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artecolombiano_298-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-artecolombiano-298">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The earliest examples of gold craftsmanship have been attributed to the Tumaco people
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
        <a href="#cite_note-299">
         [293]
        </a>
       </sup>
       of the Pacific coast and date to around 325 BCE. Roughly between 200 BCE and 800 CE, the
       <a href="/wiki/San_Agust%C3%ADn,_Huila" title="San Agustín, Huila">
        San Agustín culture
       </a>
       , masters of
       <a href="/wiki/Stonemasonry" title="Stonemasonry">
        stonecutting
       </a>
       , entered its "classical period". They erected raised
       <a href="/wiki/Ceremony" title="Ceremony">
        ceremonial
       </a>
       centres,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sarcophagi" title="Sarcophagi">
        sarcophagi
       </a>
       , and large stone
       <a href="/wiki/Monolith" title="Monolith">
        monoliths
       </a>
       depicting
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anthropomorphic" title="Anthropomorphic">
        anthropomorphic
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Zoomorphism" title="Zoomorphism">
        zoomorphhic
       </a>
       forms out of
       <a href="/wiki/Rock_(geology)" title="Rock (geology)">
        stone
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artecolombiano_298-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-artecolombiano-298">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-San_Agustín_300-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-San_Agustín-300">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Colombian art has followed the trends of the time, so during the 16th to 18th centuries,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Spain" title="Roman Catholicism in Spain">
        Spanish Catholicism
       </a>
       had a huge influence on Colombian art, and the popular
       <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">
        baroque
       </a>
       style was replaced with
       <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">
        rococo
       </a>
       when the Bourbons ascended to the
       <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Spain" title="Monarchy of Spain">
        Spanish crown
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
        <a href="#cite_note-301">
         [295]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
        <a href="#cite_note-302">
         [296]
        </a>
       </sup>
       More recently, Colombian artists
       <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Nel_G%C3%B3mez" title="Pedro Nel Gómez">
        Pedro Nel Gómez
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Santiago_Mart%C3%ADnez_Delgado" title="Santiago Martínez Delgado">
        Santiago Martínez Delgado
       </a>
       started the Colombian Murial Movement in the 1940s, featuring the
       <a href="/wiki/Neoclassicism" title="Neoclassicism">
        neoclassical
       </a>
       features of
       <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">
        Art Deco
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-donquijote.org_297-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-donquijote.org-297">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artecolombiano_298-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-artecolombiano-298">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
        <a href="#cite_note-303">
         [297]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304">
        <a href="#cite_note-304">
         [298]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the 1950s, the Colombian art started to have a distinctive point of view, reinventing traditional elements under the concepts of the 20th century. Examples of this are the Greiff
       <a href="/wiki/Portrait" title="Portrait">
        portraits
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_G%C3%B3mez_Jaramillo" title="Ignacio Gómez Jaramillo">
        Ignacio Gómez Jaramillo
       </a>
       , showing what the Colombian art could do with the new techniques applied to typical Colombian themes. Carlos Correa, with his
       <a href="/wiki/Paradigm" title="Paradigm">
        paradigmatic
       </a>
       "Naturaleza muerta en silencio" (silent dead nature), combines geometrical
       <a href="/wiki/Abstraction_(art)" title="Abstraction (art)">
        abstraction
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cubism" title="Cubism">
        cubism
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Obreg%C3%B3n" title="Alejandro Obregón">
        Alejandro Obregón
       </a>
       is often considered as the father of modern Colombian painting, and one of the most influential artist in this period, due to his originality, the painting of Colombian landscapes with
       <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" title="Symbolism (arts)">
        symbolic
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Expressionism" title="Expressionism">
        expressionist
       </a>
       use of animals, (specially the
       <a href="/wiki/Andean_condor" title="Andean condor">
        Andean condor
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artecolombiano_298-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-artecolombiano-298">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
        <a href="#cite_note-305">
         [299]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
        <a href="#cite_note-306">
         [300]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Botero" title="Fernando Botero">
        Fernando Botero
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Omar_Rayo" title="Omar Rayo">
        Omar Rayo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Grau" title="Enrique Grau">
        Enrique Grau
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%89dgar_Negret" title="Édgar Negret">
        Édgar Negret
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/David_Manzur" title="David Manzur">
        David Manzur
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Arenas_Betancourt" title="Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt">
        Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Murillo_(artist)" title="Oscar Murillo (artist)">
        Oscar Murillo
       </a>
       are some of the Colombian artists featured at the international level.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-donquijote.org_297-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-donquijote.org-297">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
        <a href="#cite_note-307">
         [301]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
        <a href="#cite_note-308">
         [302]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-museorayo_309-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-museorayo-309">
         [303]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Colombian sculpture from the sixteenth to 18th centuries was mostly devoted to
       <a href="/wiki/Religious_art" title="Religious art">
        religious depictions
       </a>
       of ecclesiastic art, strongly influenced by the Spanish schools of
       <a href="/wiki/Sacred" title="Sacred">
        sacred
       </a>
       sculpture. During the early period of the Colombian republic, the national artists were focused in the production of sculptural portraits of politicians and public figures, in a plain
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neoclassicist" title="Neoclassicist">
        neoclassicist
       </a>
       trend.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
        <a href="#cite_note-310">
         [304]
        </a>
       </sup>
       During the 20th century, the Colombian sculpture began to develop a bold and innovative work with the aim of reaching a better understanding of national sensitivity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artecolombiano_298-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-artecolombiano-298">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_sculptors_311-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_sculptors-311">
         [305]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Colombian photography was marked by the arrival of the
       <a href="/wiki/Daguerreotype" title="Daguerreotype">
        daguerreotype
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Louis_Gros" title="Jean-Baptiste Louis Gros">
        Jean-Baptiste Louis Gros
       </a>
       was who brought the daguerreotype process to Colombia in 1841. The Piloto public library has Latin America's largest archive of negatives, containing 1.7 million antique photographs covering Colombia 1848 until 2005.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312">
        <a href="#cite_note-312">
         [306]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
        <a href="#cite_note-313">
         [307]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Colombian press has promoted the work of the
       <a href="/wiki/Cartoonist" title="Cartoonist">
        cartoonists
       </a>
       . In recent decades,
       <a href="/wiki/Fanzine" title="Fanzine">
        fanzines
       </a>
       , internet and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Independent_publisher" title="Independent publisher">
        independent publishers
       </a>
       have been fundamental to the growth of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Comic" title="Comic">
        comic
       </a>
       in Colombia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
        <a href="#cite_note-314">
         [308]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
        <a href="#cite_note-315">
         [309]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
        <a href="#cite_note-316">
         [310]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">
        Architecture
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tombs_in_Tierra_Dentro_-_3.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Tombs_in_Tierra_Dentro_-_3.jpg/200px-Tombs_in_Tierra_Dentro_-_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Tombs_in_Tierra_Dentro_-_3.jpg/300px-Tombs_in_Tierra_Dentro_-_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Tombs_in_Tierra_Dentro_-_3.jpg/400px-Tombs_in_Tierra_Dentro_-_3.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Monumental hypogea of the
          <a href="/wiki/Tierradentro" title="Tierradentro">
           Tierradentro
          </a>
          culture.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Puerta_Principal._Hoy_del_Reloj_2.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3888" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Puerta_Principal._Hoy_del_Reloj_2.jpg/200px-Puerta_Principal._Hoy_del_Reloj_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Puerta_Principal._Hoy_del_Reloj_2.jpg/300px-Puerta_Principal._Hoy_del_Reloj_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Puerta_Principal._Hoy_del_Reloj_2.jpg/400px-Puerta_Principal._Hoy_del_Reloj_2.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Colonial city
          <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">
           Cartagena de Indias
          </a>
          has a military architecture characterized by solid walls and castles, colonial neighborhoods and churches.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Colombia" title="Architecture of Colombia">
        Architecture of Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Muisca_architecture" title="Muisca architecture">
        Muisca architecture
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Throughout the times, there have been a variety of
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_architectural_styles" title="List of architectural styles">
        architectural styles
       </a>
       , from those of indigenous peoples to contemporary ones, passing through colonial (military and religious), Republican, transition and modern styles.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317">
        <a href="#cite_note-317">
         [311]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Ancient habitation areas, longhouses,
       <a href="/wiki/Terrace_(agriculture)" title="Terrace (agriculture)">
        crop terraces
       </a>
       , roads as the
       <a href="/wiki/Inca_road_system" title="Inca road system">
        Inca road system
       </a>
       , cemeteries,
       <a href="/wiki/Hypogeum" title="Hypogeum">
        hypogeums
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Necropolis" title="Necropolis">
        necropolises
       </a>
       are all part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_architecture" title="Indigenous architecture">
        architectural heritage of indigenous peoples
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
        <a href="#cite_note-318">
         [312]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some prominent indigenous structures are the
       <a href="/wiki/Andean_preceramic" title="Andean preceramic">
        preceramic
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ceramic" title="Ceramic">
        ceramic
       </a>
       archaeological site of
       <a href="/wiki/Tequendama" title="Tequendama">
        Tequendama
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
        <a href="#cite_note-319">
         [313]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Tierradentro" title="Tierradentro">
        Tierradentro
       </a>
       (a park that contains the largest concentration of
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_pre-Columbian_cultures" title="List of pre-Columbian cultures">
        pre-Columbian
       </a>
       monumental
       <a href="/wiki/Shaft_tomb" title="Shaft tomb">
        shaft tombs
       </a>
       with side chambers),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
        <a href="#cite_note-320">
         [314]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the largest collection of religious
       <a href="/wiki/Monument" title="Monument">
        monuments
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megalithic" title="Megalithic">
        megalithic
       </a>
       sculptures in South America, located in
       <a href="/wiki/San_Agust%C3%ADn_Archaeological_Park" title="San Agustín Archaeological Park">
        San Agustín, Huila
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-San_Agustín_300-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-San_Agustín-300">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
        <a href="#cite_note-321">
         [315]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Perdida" title="Ciudad Perdida">
        Lost city
       </a>
       (an archaeological site with a series of terraces carved into the mountainside, a net of tiled roads and several circular plazas) and also stand out the large villages mainly built with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stone" title="Stone">
        stone
       </a>
       , wood, cane and mud.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322">
        <a href="#cite_note-322">
         [316]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="771" data-file-width="1182" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg/220px-Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg/330px-Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg/440px-Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Historic Centre of
         <a href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_de_Mompox" title="Santa Cruz de Mompox">
          Santa Cruz de Mompox
         </a>
         , an architectural site with colonial elements
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Architecture during the period of conquest and colonization is mainly derived of adapting
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_architecture" title="European architecture">
        European styles
       </a>
       to local conditions, and
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_architecture" title="Spanish architecture">
        Spanish influence
       </a>
       , especially
       <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">
        Andalusian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Extremadura" title="Extremadura">
        Extremaduran
       </a>
       , can be easily seen.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
        <a href="#cite_note-323">
         [317]
        </a>
       </sup>
       When Europeans founded cities two things were making simultaneously: the dimensioning of geometrical space (
       <a href="/wiki/Town_square" title="Town square">
        town square
       </a>
       , street), and the location of a tangible point of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Map_orientation" title="Map orientation">
        orientation
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
        <a href="#cite_note-324">
         [318]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The construction of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort" title="Fort">
        forts
       </a>
       was common throughout the Caribbean and in some cities of the interior, because of the dangers that represented the English, French, and Dutch
       <a href="/wiki/Piracy_in_the_Caribbean" title="Piracy in the Caribbean">
        pirates
       </a>
       and the hostile indigenous groups.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
        <a href="#cite_note-325">
         [319]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Churches, chapels, schools, and hospitals belonging to
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_religious_order" title="Catholic religious order">
        religious orders
       </a>
       cause a great urban impact.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1550–1750_326-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-1550–1750-326">
         [320]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Baroque_architecture" title="Baroque architecture">
        Baroque architecture
       </a>
       is used in military buildings and public spaces.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327">
        <a href="#cite_note-327">
         [321]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Marcelino Arroyo,
       <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Jos%C3%A9_de_Caldas" title="Francisco José de Caldas">
        Francisco José de Caldas
       </a>
       and Domingo de Petrés were great representatives of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neo-classical_architecture" title="Neo-classical architecture">
        neo-classical architecture
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1550–1750_326-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-1550–1750-326">
         [320]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Capitolio_Nacional" title="Capitolio Nacional">
        National Capitol
       </a>
       is a great representative of romanticism.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328">
        <a href="#cite_note-328">
         [322]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Wood is extensively used in doors, windows, railings and ceilings during the colonization of
       <a href="/wiki/Antioquia_Department" title="Antioquia Department">
        Antioquia
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_region_of_Colombia" title="Caribbean region of Colombia">
        Caribbean
       </a>
       architecture acquires a strong
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_architecture" title="Arabic architecture">
        Arabic influence
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329">
        <a href="#cite_note-329">
         [323]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Teatro_de_Crist%C3%B3bal_Col%C3%B3n" title="Teatro de Cristóbal Colón">
        Teatro Colón
       </a>
       in Bogotá is a lavish example of architecture from the 19th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330">
        <a href="#cite_note-330">
         [324]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The quintas houses with innovations in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volumetric" title="Volumetric">
        volumetric
       </a>
       conception are some of the best examples of the Republican architecture; the Republican action in the city focused on the
       <a href="/wiki/Design" title="Design">
        design
       </a>
       of three types of
       <a href="/wiki/Spatial_analysis" title="Spatial analysis">
        spaces
       </a>
       : parks with forests, small
       <a href="/wiki/Urban_park" title="Urban park">
        urban parks
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Avenue_(landscape)" title="Avenue (landscape)">
        avenues
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Gothic_architecture" title="Gothic architecture">
        Gothic style
       </a>
       was most commonly used for the design of churches.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331">
        <a href="#cite_note-331">
         [325]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Deco style,
       <a href="/wiki/Rationalism_(architecture)" title="Rationalism (architecture)">
        modern neoclassicism
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Eclecticism_in_architecture" title="Eclecticism in architecture">
        eclecticism
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folklorist" title="Folklorist">
        folklorist
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Art_deco" title="Art deco">
        art deco
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Ornament_(art)" title="Ornament (art)">
        ornamental
       </a>
       resources significantly influenced the architecture of Colombia, especially during the transition period.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332">
        <a href="#cite_note-332">
         [326]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/International_Style_(architecture)" title="International Style (architecture)">
        Modernism
       </a>
       contributed with new construction technologies and new
       <a href="/wiki/Building_material" title="Building material">
        materials
       </a>
       (steel,
       <a href="/wiki/Reinforced_concrete" title="Reinforced concrete">
        reinforced concrete
       </a>
       , glass and synthetic materials) and the
       <a href="/wiki/Topology" title="Topology">
        topology
       </a>
       architecture and
       <a href="/wiki/Concrete_slab" title="Concrete slab">
        lightened slabs system
       </a>
       also have a great influence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333">
        <a href="#cite_note-333">
         [327]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The most influential architects of the modern movement were
       <a href="/wiki/Rogelio_Salmona" title="Rogelio Salmona">
        Rogelio Salmona
       </a>
       and Fernando Martínez Sanabria.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334">
        <a href="#cite_note-334">
         [328]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_architecture" title="Contemporary architecture">
        contemporary architecture
       </a>
       of Colombia is designed to give greater importance to the
       <a href="/wiki/Building_material" title="Building material">
        materials
       </a>
       , this architecture takes into account the specific
       <a href="/wiki/Geographical_feature" title="Geographical feature">
        natural and artificial geographies
       </a>
       and is also an architecture that appeals to the
       <a href="/wiki/Sense" title="Sense">
        senses
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335">
        <a href="#cite_note-335">
         [329]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Architectural_conservation" title="Architectural conservation">
        conservation of the architectural and urban heritage
       </a>
       of Colombia has been promoted in recent years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336">
        <a href="#cite_note-336">
         [330]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">
        Music
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Colombia" title="Music of Colombia">
        Music of Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:330px;max-width:330px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:177px;max-width:177px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="12642" data-file-width="7180" height="308" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png/175px-Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png/263px-Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png/350px-Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png 2x" width="175"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Colombia" title="Music of Colombia">
           Musical Regions
          </a>
          of Colombia.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:149px;max-width:149px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tiple.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1926" data-file-width="921" height="307" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Tiple.jpg/147px-Tiple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Tiple.jpg/221px-Tiple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Tiple.jpg/294px-Tiple.jpg 2x" width="147"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Colombian_tiple" title="Colombian tiple">
           Colombian tiple
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Colombia has a vibrant collage of talent that touches a full spectrum of
       <a href="/wiki/Rhythm" title="Rhythm">
        rhythms
       </a>
       . Musicians, composers, music producers and singers from Colombia are recognized internationally such as
       <a href="/wiki/Shakira" title="Shakira">
        Shakira
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Juanes" title="Juanes">
        Juanes
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Vives" title="Carlos Vives">
        Carlos Vives
       </a>
       and others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337">
        <a href="#cite_note-337">
         [331]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombian music blends European-influenced
       <a href="/wiki/Guitar" title="Guitar">
        guitar
       </a>
       and song structure with large gaita
       <a href="/wiki/Flute" title="Flute">
        flutes
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Percussion_instrument" title="Percussion instrument">
        percussion instruments
       </a>
       from the indigenous population, while its percussion structure and
       <a href="/wiki/Dance" title="Dance">
        dance
       </a>
       forms come from Africa. Colombia has a diverse and dynamic musical environment.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-about.com_338-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-about.com-338">
         [332]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Uribe_Holgu%C3%ADn" title="Guillermo Uribe Holguín">
        Guillermo Uribe Holguín
       </a>
       , an important cultural figure in the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Symphony_Orchestra_of_Colombia" title="National Symphony Orchestra of Colombia">
        National Symphony Orchestra of Colombia
       </a>
       , Luis Antonio Calvo and Blas Emilio Atehortúa are some of the greatest exponents of the
       <a href="/wiki/Art_music" title="Art music">
        art music
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339">
        <a href="#cite_note-339">
         [333]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Bogotá Philharmonic Orchestra">
        Bogotá Philharmonic Orchestra
       </a>
       is one of the most active orchestras in Colombia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340">
        <a href="#cite_note-340">
         [334]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Caribbean music has many vibrant rhythms, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Cumbia_(Colombia)" title="Cumbia (Colombia)">
        cumbia
       </a>
       (it is played by the maracas, the drums, the gaitas and
       <a href="/wiki/Guacharaca" title="Guacharaca">
        guacharaca
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Porro" title="Porro">
        porro
       </a>
       (it is a monotonous but joyful rhythm),
       <a href="/wiki/Mapal%C3%A9" title="Mapalé">
        mapalé
       </a>
       (with its fast rhythm and constant clapping) and the "
       <a href="/wiki/Vallenato" title="Vallenato">
        vallenato
       </a>
       ", which originated in the northern part of the Caribbean coast (the rhythm is mainly played by the caja, the guacharaca, and
       <a href="/wiki/Accordion" title="Accordion">
        accordion
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_music_341-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_music-341">
         [335]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342">
        <a href="#cite_note-342">
         [336]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343">
        <a href="#cite_note-343">
         [337]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344">
        <a href="#cite_note-344">
         [338]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345">
        <a href="#cite_note-345">
         [339]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The music from the Pacific coast, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Currulao_(music_genre)" title="Currulao (music genre)">
        currulao
       </a>
       is characterized by its strong use of
       <a href="/wiki/Drum" title="Drum">
        drums
       </a>
       (instruments such as the native
       <a href="/wiki/Marimba" title="Marimba">
        marimba
       </a>
       , the conunos, the
       <a href="/wiki/Bass_drum" title="Bass drum">
        bass drum
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Side_drum" title="Side drum">
        side drum
       </a>
       and the cuatro guasas or tubular rattle). An important rhythm of the south region of the Pacific coast is the
       <a href="/wiki/Contradanza" title="Contradanza">
        contradanza
       </a>
       (it is used in dance shows, as a result of the striking colours of the costumes).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_music_341-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_music-341">
         [335]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346">
        <a href="#cite_note-346">
         [340]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347">
        <a href="#cite_note-347">
         [341]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Marimba music, traditional chants and dances from the Colombia South Pacific region are on
       <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">
        UNESCO's Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348">
        <a href="#cite_note-348">
         [342]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349">
        <a href="#cite_note-349">
         [343]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350">
        <a href="#cite_note-350">
         [344]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Important musical rhythms of the Andean Region are the danza (dance of Andean folklore arising from the transformation of the European contredance), the
       <a href="/wiki/Bambuco" title="Bambuco">
        bambuco
       </a>
       (it is played with guitar,
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_tiple" title="Colombian tiple">
        tiple
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351">
        <a href="#cite_note-351">
         [345]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Mandolin" title="Mandolin">
        mandolin
       </a>
       , the rhythm is danced by couples), the
       <a href="/wiki/Pasillo" title="Pasillo">
        pasillo
       </a>
       (a rhythm inspired by the Austrian
       <a href="/wiki/Waltz" title="Waltz">
        waltz
       </a>
       and the Colombian "danza", the lyrics have been composed by well-known poets), the guabina (the tiple, the
       <a href="/wiki/Bandola" title="Bandola">
        bandola
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Requinto" title="Requinto">
        requinto
       </a>
       are the basic instruments), the
       <a href="/wiki/Sanjuanero" title="Sanjuanero">
        sanjuanero
       </a>
       (it originated in Tolima and Huila Departments, the rhythm is joyful and fast).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352">
        <a href="#cite_note-352">
         [346]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353">
        <a href="#cite_note-353">
         [347]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354">
        <a href="#cite_note-354">
         [348]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355">
        <a href="#cite_note-355">
         [349]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356">
        <a href="#cite_note-356">
         [350]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Apart from these traditional rhythms,
       <a href="/wiki/Salsa_music" title="Salsa music">
        salsa music
       </a>
       has spread throughout the country, and the city of
       <a href="/wiki/Cali" title="Cali">
        Cali
       </a>
       is considered by many salsa singers to be 'The New Salsa Capital of the World'.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_music_341-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_music-341">
         [335]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357">
        <a href="#cite_note-357">
         [351]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358">
        <a href="#cite_note-358">
         [352]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <div class="PopUpMediaTransform" id="mwe_player_1" style="width:220px;" videopayload='&lt;div class="mediaContainer" style="width:854px"&gt;&lt;video id="mwe_player_2" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm/854px--Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm.jpg" controls="" preload="none" autoplay="" style="width:854px;height:480px" class="kskin" data-durationhint="134.134" data-startoffset="0" data-mwtitle="Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons"&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a7/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm.480p.webm" type="video/webm;
