codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="HD WebM (720P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 720P" data-transcodekey="720p.webm" data-width="1280" data-height="720" data-bandwidth="3579872" data-framerate="23.976"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a7/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm.160p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Low bandwidth WebM (160P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 160P" data-transcodekey="160p.webm" data-width="284" data-height="160" data-bandwidth="201632" data-framerate="23.976"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a7/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm.240p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" data-transcodekey="240p.webm" data-width="426" data-height="240" data-bandwidth="317720" data-framerate="23.976"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a7/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm.360p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360" data-bandwidth="567984" data-framerate="23.976"/&gt;&lt;/video&gt;&lt;/div&gt;'>
         <img alt="File:Bailarines de Salsa en Cali.webm" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm/220px--Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm.jpg" style="width:220px;height:124px"/>
         <a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a7/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm" target="new" title="Play media">
          <span class="play-btn-large">
           <span class="mw-tmh-playtext">
            Play media
           </span>
          </span>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Colombian-style salsa dancing
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The instruments that distinguish the music of the
       <a href="/wiki/Orinoqu%C3%ADa_natural_region" title="Orinoquía natural region">
        Eastern Plains
       </a>
       are the
       <a href="/wiki/Harp" title="Harp">
        harp
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Cuatro_(instrument)" title="Cuatro (instrument)">
        cuatro
       </a>
       (a type of four-stringed guitar) and maracas. Important rhythms of this region are the
       <a href="/wiki/Joropo" title="Joropo">
        joropo
       </a>
       (a fast rhythm and there is also tapping as a result of its
       <a href="/wiki/Flamenco" title="Flamenco">
        flamenco
       </a>
       ancestry) and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Galeron" title="Galeron">
        galeron
       </a>
       (it is heard a lot while cowboys are working).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_music_341-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_music-341">
         [335]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359">
        <a href="#cite_note-359">
         [353]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360">
        <a href="#cite_note-360">
         [354]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361">
        <a href="#cite_note-361">
         [355]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The music of the Amazon region is strongly influenced by the indigenous religious practices. Some of the musical instruments used are the manguaré (a musical instrument of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ceremonial" title="Ceremonial">
        ceremonial
       </a>
       type, consisting of a pair of large cylindrical drums), the
       <a href="/wiki/Quena" title="Quena">
        quena
       </a>
       (melodic instrument), the
       <a href="/wiki/Rondador" title="Rondador">
        rondador
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Conga" title="Conga">
        congas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bell" title="Bell">
        bells
       </a>
       , and different types of flutes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362">
        <a href="#cite_note-362">
         [356]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363">
        <a href="#cite_note-363">
         [357]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364">
        <a href="#cite_note-364">
         [358]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The music of the Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina is usually accompanied by a mandolin, a
       <a href="/wiki/Washtub_bass" title="Washtub bass">
        tub-bass
       </a>
       , a jawbone, a guitar and
       <a href="/wiki/Maraca" title="Maraca">
        maracas
       </a>
       . Some popular archipelago rhythms are the
       <a href="/wiki/Schottische" title="Schottische">
        Schottische
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Calypso_music" title="Calypso music">
        Calypso
       </a>
       , the Polka and the
       <a href="/wiki/Mento" title="Mento">
        Mento
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365">
        <a href="#cite_note-365">
         [359]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366">
        <a href="#cite_note-366">
         [360]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Popular_culture">
        Popular culture
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Theater_of_Colombia" title="Theater of Colombia">
        Theater of Colombia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Colombia" title="Cinema of Colombia">
        Cinema of Colombia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Colombia" title="Media of Colombia">
        Media of Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg/180px-Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg/270px-Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg/360px-Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Ibero-American Theater Festival of Bogotá is one of the biggest theater festivals in the world.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Theater_Festival_367-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Theater_Festival-367">
           [361]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Theater was introduced in Colombia during the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">
        Spanish colonization
       </a>
       in 1550 through
       <a href="/wiki/Zarzuela" title="Zarzuela">
        zarzuela
       </a>
       companies. Colombian theater is supported by the Ministry of Culture and a number of private and state owned organizations. The
       <a href="/wiki/Theater_of_Colombia" title="Theater of Colombia">
        Ibero-American Theater Festival of Bogotá
       </a>
       is the cultural event of the highest importance in Colombia and one of the biggest theater festivals in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Theater_Festival_367-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Theater_Festival-367">
         [361]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other important theater events are: The Festival of Puppet The Fanfare (Medellín), The Manizales Theater Festival, The Caribbean Theatre Festival (Santa Marta) and The Art Festival of Popular Culture "Cultural Invasion" (Bogotá).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Theatre_in_Colombia_368-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Theatre_in_Colombia-368">
         [362]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theatrical_production_369-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-theatrical_production-369">
         [363]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-teatro_siglo_XX_370-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-teatro_siglo_XX-370">
         [364]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1283" data-file-width="1600" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG/200px-Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG/300px-Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG/400px-Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Cartagena_Film_Festival" title="Cartagena Film Festival">
          Cartagena Film Festival
         </a>
         is the oldest cinema event in Latin America. The central focus is on films from Ibero-America.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fiapf_371-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-fiapf-371">
           [365]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Although the
       <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Colombia" title="Cinema of Colombia">
        Colombian cinema
       </a>
       is young as an industry, more recently the film industry was growing with support from the Film Act passed in 2003.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-the_Film_Act_passed_in_2003_372-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-the_Film_Act_passed_in_2003-372">
         [366]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many film festivals take place in Colombia, but the two most important are the
       <a href="/wiki/Cartagena_Film_Festival" title="Cartagena Film Festival">
        Cartagena Film Festival
       </a>
       , which is the oldest film festival in Latin America, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1_Film_Festival" title="Bogotá Film Festival">
        Bogotá Film Festival
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fiapf_371-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-fiapf-371">
         [365]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-film_festivals_373-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-film_festivals-373">
         [367]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374">
        <a href="#cite_note-374">
         [368]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some important national circulation newspapers are
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/El_Tiempo_(Colombia)" title="El Tiempo (Colombia)">
         El Tiempo
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/El_Espectador" title="El Espectador">
         El Espectador
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Colombia" title="Television in Colombia">
        Television in Colombia
       </a>
       has two privately owned TV networks and three state-owned TV networks with national coverage, as well as six regional TV networks and dozens of local TV stations. Private channels,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RCN_TV" title="RCN TV">
        RCN
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Caracol_Televisi%C3%B3n" title="Caracol Televisión">
        Caracol
       </a>
       are the highest-rated. The regional channels and regional newspapers cover a department or more and its content is made in these particular areas.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Television_in_Colombia_375-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Television_in_Colombia-375">
         [369]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-press_376-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-press-376">
         [370]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_press_in_Colombia_377-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-The_press_in_Colombia-377">
         [371]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Colombia has three major national
       <a href="/wiki/Radio_in_Colombia" title="Radio in Colombia">
        radio networks
       </a>
       :
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radiodifusora_Nacional_de_Colombia" title="Radiodifusora Nacional de Colombia">
        Radiodifusora Nacional de Colombia
       </a>
       , a state-run national radio;
       <a href="/wiki/Caracol_Radio" title="Caracol Radio">
        Caracol Radio
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/RCN_Radio" title="RCN Radio">
        RCN Radio
       </a>
       , privately owned networks with hundreds of affiliates. There are other national networks, including
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cadena_Super" title="Cadena Super">
        Cadena Super
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Todelar" title="Todelar">
        Todelar
       </a>
       , and Colmundo. Many hundreds of radio stations are registered with the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Information_Technologies_and_Communications_(Colombia)" title="Ministry of Information Technologies and Communications (Colombia)">
        Ministry of Information Technologies and Communications
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Radio_in_Colombia_378-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Radio_in_Colombia-378">
         [372]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Colombian_cuisine" title="Colombian cuisine">
        Colombian cuisine
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="320" data-file-width="630" height="112" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg/220px-Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg/330px-Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg/440px-Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Sancocho de gallina criolla is a traditional soup in Colombia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Colombia's varied cuisine is influenced by its diverse fauna and flora as well as the cultural traditions of the ethnic groups. Colombian dishes and ingredients vary widely by region. Some of the most common ingredients are: cereals such as rice and maize; tubers such as potato and
       <a href="/wiki/Cassava" title="Cassava">
        cassava
       </a>
       ; assorted
       <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">
        legumes
       </a>
       ; meats, including beef, chicken, pork and goat; fish; and seafood.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paseo_de_olla_379-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Paseo_de_olla-379">
         [373]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380">
        <a href="#cite_note-380">
         [374]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia cuisine also features a variety of tropical
       <a href="/wiki/Fruit" title="Fruit">
        fruits
       </a>
       such as
       <a href="/wiki/Physalis_peruviana" title="Physalis peruviana">
        cape gooseberry
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Acca_sellowiana" title="Acca sellowiana">
        feijoa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Eugenia_stipitata" title="Eugenia stipitata">
        arazá
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pitaya" title="Pitaya">
        dragon fruit
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Purple_mangosteen" title="Purple mangosteen">
        mangostino
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Passiflora_ligularis" title="Passiflora ligularis">
        granadilla
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Papaya" title="Papaya">
        papaya
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Guava" title="Guava">
        guava
       </a>
       , mora (
       <a href="/wiki/Blackberry" title="Blackberry">
        blackberry
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Solanum_quitoense" title="Solanum quitoense">
        lulo
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Annona_muricata" title="Annona muricata">
        soursop
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Passionfruit" title="Passionfruit">
        passionfruit
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_cuisine_381-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_cuisine-381">
         [375]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia is one of the world's largest consumers of fruit
       <a href="/wiki/Juice" title="Juice">
        juices
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382">
        <a href="#cite_note-382">
         [376]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Among the most representative appetizers and soups are
       <a href="/wiki/Tostones" title="Tostones">
        patacones
       </a>
       (fried green plantains),
       <a href="/wiki/Sancocho" title="Sancocho">
        sancocho
       </a>
       de gallina (chicken soup with root vegetables) and
       <a href="/wiki/Ajiaco" title="Ajiaco">
        ajiaco
       </a>
       (potato and corn soup). Representative snacks and breads are
       <a href="/wiki/Pandebono" title="Pandebono">
        pandebono
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Arepa" title="Arepa">
        arepas
       </a>
       (corn cakes),
       <a href="/wiki/Aborrajado" title="Aborrajado">
        aborrajados
       </a>
       (fried sweet plantains with cheese),
       <a href="/wiki/Torta" title="Torta">
        torta
       </a>
       de
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Choclo" title="Choclo">
        choclo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Empanada" title="Empanada">
        empanadas
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Almoj%C3%A1bana" title="Almojábana">
        almojábanas
       </a>
       . Representative main courses are
       <a href="/wiki/Bandeja_paisa" title="Bandeja paisa">
        bandeja paisa
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lechona_tolimense" title="Lechona tolimense">
        lechona tolimense
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ternera_a_la_llanera" title="Ternera a la llanera">
        mamona
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tamales" title="Tamales">
        tamales
       </a>
       and fish dishes (such as
       <a href="/wiki/Arroz_de_lisa" title="Arroz de lisa">
        arroz de lisa
       </a>
       ), especially in coastal regions where
       <a href="/wiki/Kibbeh" title="Kibbeh">
        kibbeh
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Suero" title="Suero">
        suero
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Coste%C3%B1o_cheese" title="Costeño cheese">
        costeño cheese
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Carima%C3%B1ola" title="Carimañola">
        carimañolas
       </a>
       are also eaten. Representative side dishes are papas chorreadas (potatoes with cheese), remolachas rellenas con huevo duro (beets stuffed with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hard-boiled_egg" title="Hard-boiled egg">
        hard-boiled egg
       </a>
       ) and
       <a href="/wiki/Coconut_rice" title="Coconut rice">
        arroz con coco
       </a>
       (coconut rice).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_cuisine_381-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_cuisine-381">
         [375]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paseo_de_olla_379-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Paseo_de_olla-379">
         [373]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Organic_food" title="Organic food">
        Organic food
       </a>
       is a current trend in big cities, although in general across the country the fruits and veggies are very natural and fresh.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383">
        <a href="#cite_note-383">
         [377]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_Food_384-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_Food-384">
         [378]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Representative desserts are
       <a href="/wiki/Bu%C3%B1uelo" title="Buñuelo">
        buñuelos
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natilla" title="Natilla">
        natillas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Maria_Luisa_cake" title="Maria Luisa cake">
        Maria Luisa cake
       </a>
       , bocadillo made of guayaba (
       <a href="/wiki/Guava_jelly" title="Guava jelly">
        guava jelly
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Cocadas" title="Cocadas">
        cocadas
       </a>
       (coconut balls), casquitos de guayaba (candied guava peels),
       <a href="/wiki/Torta_de_nata" title="Torta de nata">
        torta de natas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Oblea" title="Oblea">
        obleas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Flan" title="Flan">
        flan
       </a>
       de
       <a href="/wiki/Mango" title="Mango">
        mango
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rosc%C3%B3n" title="Roscón">
        roscón
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Milhoja" title="Milhoja">
        milhoja
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Manjar_blanco" title="Manjar blanco">
        manjar blanco
       </a>
       , dulce de
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feijoa" title="Feijoa">
        feijoa
       </a>
       , dulce de
       <a href="/wiki/Mountain_papaya" title="Mountain papaya">
        papayuela
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Torta" title="Torta">
        torta
       </a>
       de mojicón, and esponjado de
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Curuba" title="Curuba">
        curuba
       </a>
       . Typical sauces (salsas) are
       <a href="/wiki/Hogao" title="Hogao">
        hogao
       </a>
       (tomato and onion sauce) and Colombian-style
       <a href="/wiki/Aj%C3%AD_(sauce)" title="Ají (sauce)">
        ají
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_cuisine_381-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_cuisine-381">
         [375]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paseo_de_olla_379-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Paseo_de_olla-379">
         [373]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some representative beverages are
       <a href="/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Colombia" title="Coffee production in Colombia">
        coffee
       </a>
       (Tinto),
       <a href="/wiki/Champ%C3%BAs" title="Champús">
        champús
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cholado" title="Cholado">
        cholado
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lulada" title="Lulada">
        lulada
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avena_(beverage)" title="Avena (beverage)">
        avena
       </a>
       colombiana,
       <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">
        sugarcane
       </a>
       juice,
       <a href="/wiki/Aguapanela" title="Aguapanela">
        aguapanela
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Aguardiente" title="Aguardiente">
        aguardiente
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hot_chocolate" title="Hot chocolate">
        hot chocolate
       </a>
       and fresh fruit juices (often made with water or milk).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_cuisine_381-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_cuisine-381">
         [375]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paseo_de_olla_379-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-Paseo_de_olla-379">
         [373]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Colombia" title="Sport in Colombia">
        Sport in Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nairo_Quintana,_Paris-Nice_2013.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1065" data-file-width="1600" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Nairo_Quintana%2C_Paris-Nice_2013.JPG/220px-Nairo_Quintana%2C_Paris-Nice_2013.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Nairo_Quintana%2C_Paris-Nice_2013.JPG/330px-Nairo_Quintana%2C_Paris-Nice_2013.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Nairo_Quintana%2C_Paris-Nice_2013.JPG/440px-Nairo_Quintana%2C_Paris-Nice_2013.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nairo_Quintana,_Paris-Nice_2013.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Nairo_Quintana" title="Nairo Quintana">
          Nairo Quintana
         </a>
         : Colombian Champion of the
         <a href="/wiki/Giro_d%27Italia" title="Giro d'Italia">
          Giro d'Italia
         </a>
         and the
         <a href="/wiki/Vuelta_a_Espa%C3%B1a" title="Vuelta a España">
          Vuelta a España
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:247px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="616" data-file-width="960" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg/245px-Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg/368px-Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg/490px-Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg 2x" width="245"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Colombia is a perennial powerhouse at the
         <a href="/wiki/Inline_speed_skating" title="Inline speed skating">
          World Roller Speed Skating Championships
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Tejo_(sport)" title="Tejo (sport)">
        Tejo
       </a>
       is Colombia's national sport and is a team sport that involves launching projectiles to hit a target.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tejo-Colombia's_national_sport._385-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tejo-Colombia's_national_sport.-385">
         [379]
        </a>
       </sup>
       But of all sports in Colombia,
       <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
        football
       </a>
       is the most popular.
       <a href="/wiki/Colombia_national_football_team" title="Colombia national football team">
        Colombia
       </a>
       was the champion of the
       <a href="/wiki/2001_Copa_Am%C3%A9rica" title="2001 Copa América">
        2001 Copa América
       </a>
       , in which they set a new record of being undefeated, conceding no goals and winning each match. Interestingly, Colombia has been awarded "
       <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings#Best_Mover_of_the_Year" title="FIFA World Rankings">
        mover of the year
       </a>
       " twice.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386">
        <a href="#cite_note-386">
         [380]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Colombia is a hub for
       <a href="/wiki/Inline_speed_skating" title="Inline speed skating">
        roller skaters
       </a>
       . The national team is a perennial powerhouse at the World Roller Speed Skating Championships.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Patinaje_colombiano_387-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Patinaje_colombiano-387">
         [381]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Colombia has traditionally been very good in
       <a href="/wiki/Cycle_sport" title="Cycle sport">
        cycling
       </a>
       and a large number of Colombian cyclists have triumphed in major competitions of cycling.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_cycling_388-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_cycling-388">
         [382]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Baseball is popular in the Caribbean, mainly in the cities
       <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">
        Cartagena
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Barranquilla" title="Barranquilla">
        Barranquilla
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Marta" title="Santa Marta">
        Santa Marta
       </a>
       . Of those cities have come good players like:
       <a href="/wiki/Orlando_Cabrera" title="Orlando Cabrera">
        Orlando Cabrera
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%89dgar_Renter%C3%ADa" title="Édgar Rentería">
        Édgar Rentería
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389">
        <a href="#cite_note-389">
         [383]
        </a>
       </sup>
       who was champion of the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Series" title="World Series">
        World Series
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/1997_World_Series" title="1997 World Series">
        1997
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/2010_World_Series" title="2010 World Series">
        2010
       </a>
       , and others who have played in
       <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">
        Major League Baseball
       </a>
       . Colombia was
       <a href="/wiki/Baseball_World_Cup" title="Baseball World Cup">
        world amateur champion
       </a>
       in 1947 and 1965.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-béisbolglorias_390-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-béisbolglorias-390">
         [384]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">
        Boxing
       </a>
       is one of the sports that more world champions has produced for Colombia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_of_boxing_391-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-History_of_boxing-391">
         [385]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boxing_champions_392-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Boxing_champions-392">
         [386]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Motorsport" title="Motorsport">
        Motorsports
       </a>
       also occupies an important place in the sporting preferences of Colombians;
       <a href="/wiki/Juan_Pablo_Montoya" title="Juan Pablo Montoya">
        Juan Pablo Montoya
       </a>
       is a race car driver known for winning 7 Formula One events. Colombia also has excelled in sports such as
       <a href="/wiki/UCI_BMX_World_Championships" title="UCI BMX World Championships">
        BMX
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Judo" title="Judo">
        judo
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shooting_sport" title="Shooting sport">
        shooting sport
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Taekwondo" title="Taekwondo">
        taekwondo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">
        wrestling
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/High_diving" title="High diving">
        high diving
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sport_of_athletics" title="Sport of athletics">
        athletics
       </a>
       , also has a long tradition in
       <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">
        weightlifting
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bowling" title="Bowling">
        bowling
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393">
        <a href="#cite_note-393">
         [387]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394">
        <a href="#cite_note-394">
         [388]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395">
        <a href="#cite_note-395">
         [389]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Health">
        Health
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Colombia" title="Health care in Colombia">
        Health care in Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:345px;max-width:345px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:153px;max-width:153px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Instituto_del_Coraz%C3%B3n_-_Fundaci%C3%B3n_Cardiovascular_de_Colombia.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="3664" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Instituto_del_Coraz%C3%B3n_-_Fundaci%C3%B3n_Cardiovascular_de_Colombia.JPG/151px-Instituto_del_Coraz%C3%B3n_-_Fundaci%C3%B3n_Cardiovascular_de_Colombia.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Instituto_del_Coraz%C3%B3n_-_Fundaci%C3%B3n_Cardiovascular_de_Colombia.JPG/227px-Instituto_del_Coraz%C3%B3n_-_Fundaci%C3%B3n_Cardiovascular_de_Colombia.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Instituto_del_Coraz%C3%B3n_-_Fundaci%C3%B3n_Cardiovascular_de_Colombia.JPG/302px-Instituto_del_Coraz%C3%B3n_-_Fundaci%C3%B3n_Cardiovascular_de_Colombia.JPG 2x" width="151"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:188px;max-width:188px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FVL_Clinica_Cali.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1023" data-file-width="1469" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/FVL_Clinica_Cali.JPG/186px-FVL_Clinica_Cali.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/FVL_Clinica_Cali.JPG/279px-FVL_Clinica_Cali.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/FVL_Clinica_Cali.JPG/372px-FVL_Clinica_Cali.JPG 2x" width="186"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">
         Colombia leads the annual ranking of the best clinics and hospitals in Latin America.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_clinics_396-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_clinics-396">
           [390]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The overall
       <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">
        life expectancy
       </a>
       in Colombia at birth is 74.8 years (71.2 years for males and 78.4 years for females).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Life_expectancy_at_birth_253-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Life_expectancy_at_birth-253">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Health standards in Colombia have improved very much since the 1980s, healthcare reforms have led to the massive improvements in the healthcare systems of the country. Although this new system has widened population coverage by the social and health security system from 21% (pre-1993) to 96% in 2012,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397">
        <a href="#cite_note-397">
         [391]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Health_equity" title="Health equity">
        health disparities
       </a>
       persist.
      </p>
      <p>
       Through
       <a href="/wiki/Medical_tourism" title="Medical tourism">
        health tourism
       </a>
       , many people from over the world travel from their places of residence to other countries in search of medical treatment and the attractions in the countries visited. Colombia is projected as one of Latin America's main destinations in terms of health tourism due to the quality of its
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Health_care_professional" title="Health care professional">
        health care professionals
       </a>
       , a good number of institutions devoted to health, and an immense inventory of natural and architectural sites. Cities such as Bogotá, Cali, Medellín and Bucaramanga are the most visited in
       <a href="/wiki/Cardiology" title="Cardiology">
        cardiology
       </a>
       procedures,
       <a href="/wiki/Neurology" title="Neurology">
        neurology
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dental_treatment" title="Dental treatment">
        dental treatments
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stem_cell_therapy" title="Stem cell therapy">
        stem cell therapy
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Otorhinolaryngology" title="Otorhinolaryngology">
        ENT
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ophthalmology" title="Ophthalmology">
        ophthalmology
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Joint_replacement" title="Joint replacement">
        joint replacements
       </a>
       because of the quality of medical treatment.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398">
        <a href="#cite_note-398">
         [392]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A study conducted by
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Am%C3%A9rica_Econom%C3%ADa" title="América Economía">
         América Economía
        </a>
       </i>
       magazine ranked 21 Colombian
       <a href="/wiki/Health_facility" title="Health facility">
        health care institutions
       </a>
       among the top 44 in Latin America, amounting to 48 percent of the total.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_clinics_396-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Colombian_clinics-396">
         [390]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A
       <a href="/wiki/Cancer_research" title="Cancer research">
        cancer research
       </a>
       and treatment centre was declared as a Project of National Strategic Interest.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399">
        <a href="#cite_note-399">
         [393]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Colombia" title="Education in Colombia">
        Education in Colombia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG/200px-UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG/300px-UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG/400px-UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         M5 building –
         <a href="/wiki/National_University_of_Colombia" title="National University of Colombia">
          National University of Colombia
         </a>
         , designed by
         <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Nel_G%C3%B3mez" title="Pedro Nel Gómez">
          Pedro Nel Gómez
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Universidad_de_los_Andes_(3326108271).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg/200px-Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg/300px-Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg/400px-Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Universidad_de_los_Andes_(3326108271).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Mario Laserna Building –
         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Los_Andes_(Colombia)" title="University of Los Andes (Colombia)">
          University of Los Andes
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The educational experience of many Colombian children begins with attendance at a
       <a href="/wiki/Preschool" title="Preschool">
        preschool
       </a>
       academy until age five (
       <i>
        Educación preescolar
       </i>
       ). Basic education (
       <i>
        Educación básica
       </i>
       ) is compulsory by law.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400">
        <a href="#cite_note-400">
         [394]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It has two stages: Primary basic education (
       <i>
        Educación básica primaria
       </i>
       ) which goes from first to fifth grade – children from six to ten years old, and Secondary basic education (
       <i>
        Educación básica secundaria
       </i>
       ), which goes from sixth to ninth grade. Basic education is followed by Middle vocational education (
       <i>
        Educación media vocacional
       </i>
       ) that comprises the tenth and eleventh grades. It may have different vocational training modalities or specialties (academic, technical, business, and so on.) according to the curriculum adopted by each school.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sistema_educativo_401-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-sistema_educativo-401">
         [395]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       After the successful completion of all the basic and middle education years, a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-school_diploma" title="High-school diploma">
        high-school diploma
       </a>
       is awarded. The high-school graduate is known as a
       <i>
        bachiller
       </i>
       , because secondary basic school and middle education are traditionally considered together as a unit called
       <i>
        bachillerato
       </i>
       (sixth to eleventh grade). Students in their final year of middle education take the
       <a href="/wiki/ICFES_Examination" title="ICFES Examination">
        ICFES test
       </a>
       (now renamed Saber 11) in order to gain access to higher education (
       <i>
        Educación superior
       </i>
       ). This higher education includes undergraduate professional studies, technical, technological and intermediate professional education, and post-graduate studies. Technical professional institutions of Higher Education are also opened to students holder of a qualification in Arts and Business. This qualification is usually awarded by the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Service_of_Learning_(Colombia)" title="National Service of Learning (Colombia)">
        SENA
       </a>
       after a two years
       <a href="/wiki/Curriculum" title="Curriculum">
        curriculum
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402">
        <a href="#cite_note-402">
         [396]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <i>
        Bachilleres
       </i>
       (high-school graduates) may enter into a professional undergraduate career program offered by a university; these programs last up to five years (or less for technical, technological and intermediate professional education, and post-graduate studies), even as much to six to seven years for some careers, such as medicine. In Colombia, there is not an institution such as college; students go directly into a career program at a university or any other educational institution to obtain a professional, technical or technological title. Once graduated from the university, people are granted a (professional, technical or technological) diploma and licensed (if required) to practice the career they have chosen. For some professional career programs, students are required to take the Saber-Pro test, in their final year of undergraduate academic education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sistema_educativo_401-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-sistema_educativo-401">
         [395]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Public spending on education as a proportion of gross domestic product in 2015 was 4.49%. This represented 15.05% of total government expenditure. The
       <a href="/wiki/Gross_enrolment_ratio" title="Gross enrolment ratio">
        primary and secondary gross enrolment ratios
       </a>
       stood at 113.56% and 98.09% respectively.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/School-life_expectancy" title="School-life expectancy">
        School-life expectancy
       </a>
       was 14.42 years. A total of 94.58% of the population aged 15 and older were recorded as literate, including 98.66% of those aged 15–24.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNESCO_255-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNESCO-255">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
        Notes
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references">
         <li id="cite_note-11">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-11">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           IPA transcription of "
           <i>
            República de Colombia
           </i>
           ":
           <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
            <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">
             [reˈpuβlika ðe koˈlombja]
            </a>
           </span>
           .
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-31">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-31">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Balboa is best known for being the first European to see the Pacific Ocean in 1513, which he called
           <i>
            Mar del Sur
           </i>
           (or "Sea of the South") and would facilitate Spanish exploration and settlement of South America.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-57">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-57">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           A royal decree of 1713 approved the legality of
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palenque_de_San_Basilio" title="Palenque de San Basilio">
            Palenque de San Basilio
           </a>
           founded by runaway slaves as a refuge in the seventeenth century. The people of San Basilio fought against slavery, thereby giving rise to the first free place in the Americas.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
            <a href="#cite_note-55">
             [53]
            </a>
           </sup>
           Its main leader was
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benkos_Bioho" title="Benkos Bioho">
            Benkos Biohó
           </a>
           , who was born in
           <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">
            West Africa
           </a>
           .
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
            <a href="#cite_note-56">
             [54]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-60">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-60">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="/wiki/Peter_Claver" title="Peter Claver">
            Peter Claver
           </a>
           was a Spanish who traveled to Cartagena in 1610 and was ordained as a
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesuit" title="Jesuit">
            Jesuit
           </a>
           priest in 1616. Peter cared for the African slaves for thirty-eight years, defending the life and the
           <a href="/wiki/Dignity" title="Dignity">
            dignity
           </a>
           of the slaves.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
            <a href="#cite_note-58">
             [55]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
            <a href="#cite_note-59">
             [56]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-112">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-112">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A9ctor_Abad_G%C3%B3mez" title="Héctor Abad Gómez">
            Héctor Abad
           </a>
           was a prominent medical doctor, university professor, and human rights leader whose holistic vision of healthcare led him to found the Colombian National School of
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_Health" title="Public Health">
            Public Health
           </a>
           . The increasing violence and human rights abuses of the 1970s and 1980s led him to fight for social justice in his community.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
            <a href="#cite_note-110">
             [106]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
            <a href="#cite_note-111">
             [107]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-114">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-114">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="/wiki/Javier_de_Nicol%C3%B3" title="Javier de Nicoló">
            Javier de Nicoló
           </a>
           was a
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salesian" title="Salesian">
            Salesian
           </a>
           priest who grew up in war-torn Italy and arrived in Colombia a year after the bogotazo. He developed a program that has offered more than 40,000 young people the education and moral support they needed to become productive citizens.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
            <a href="#cite_note-113">
             [108]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </li>
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Mataron+a+Gait%C3%A1n%3A+vida+p%C3%BAblica+y+violencia+urbana+en+Colombia&amp;rft.pub=Universidad+Nacional+de+Colombia%2C+Centro+Editorial&amp;rft.date=1987&amp;rft.isbn=9789581700066&amp;rft.au=Braun%2C+Herbert&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          <span class="error citation-comment" style="display:none;font-size:100%">
           Missing or empty
           <code style="color:inherit; border:inherit; padding:inherit;">
            |url=
           </code>
           (
           <a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#cite_web_url" title="Help:CS1 errors">
            help

          </span>
         </span>

        <li id="cite_note-Encarta-99">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Encarta_99-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Charles Bergquist; David J. Robinson (1997–2005).
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.webcitation.org/5kwsWoGia?url=http://ca.encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761564636_10/Colombia.html" rel="nofollow">
            "Colombia"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            Microsoft Encarta Online Encyclopedia 2005
           </i>
           . Microsoft Corporation. Archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://ca.encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761564636_10/Colombia.html" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>
           on 1 November 2009
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             16 April
            </span>
            2006
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Microsoft+Encarta+Online+Encyclopedia+2005&amp;rft.atitle=Colombia&amp;rft.date=1997%2F2005&amp;rft.au=Charles+Bergquist&amp;rft.au=David+J.+Robinson&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fca.encarta.msn.com%2Fencyclopedia_761564636_10%2FColombia.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          <i>
           On 9 April 1948, Gaitán was assassinated outside his law offices in downtown Bogotá. The assassination marked the start of a decade of bloodshed, called
          </i>
          La Violencia
          <i>
           (The Violence), which took the lives of an estimated 180,000 Colombians before it subsided in 1958.
          </i>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Colombia's_legacy_with_Korea-100">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Colombia's_legacy_with_Korea_100-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>

           </a>
           <span style="font-size:85%;">
            (PDF)
           </span>
           (in Spanish). The Kellogg Institute for International Studies.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Colombia+y+los+Estados+Unidos+en+la+Guerra+de+Corea&amp;rft.pub=The+Kellogg+Institute+for+International+Studies&amp;rft.date=1986&amp;rft.au=Carlos+Horacio+Ur%C3%A1n&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fkellogg.nd.edu%2Fpublications%2Fworkingpapers%2FWPS%2F069.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-101">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-101">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Atehortúa Cruz, Adolfo León.
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.scielo.org.co/pdf/folios/n31/n31a03.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            "El golpe de Rojas y el poder de los militares"
           </a>
           <span style="font-size:85%;">
            (PDF)
           </span>
           (in Spanish). scielo.org.co.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=El+golpe+de+Rojas+y+el+poder+de+los+militares&amp;rft.pub=scielo.org.co&amp;rft.au=Atehort%C3%BAa+Cruz%2C+Adolfo+Le%C3%B3n&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.scielo.org.co%2Fpdf%2Ffolios%2Fn31%2Fn31a03.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia">

        <li id="cite_note-1550–1750-326">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-1550–1750_326-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-1550–1750_326-1">
           <sup>
            <i>

            ^

         <span class="reference-text">

                           </a>

                       <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_the_South" title="Bank of the South">

                       </a>

       <li id="t-wikibase">
        <a accesskey="g" href="https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Special:EntityPage/Q739" title="Link to connected data repository item [g]">
         Wikidata item
        </a>

      </ul>
